projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: GREAT BRITAIN's COASTING-PILOT.
The FIRST PART.
Being a New and Exact SURVEY of the Sea-Coa≈øt OF ENGLAND, FROM THE RIVER of THAMES TO THE WESTWARD, WITH THE ISLANDS of SCILLY, And from thence to CARLILE.

DESCRIBING All the Harbours, Rivers, Bays, Roads, Rocks, Sands, Buoys, Beacons, Sea-Marks, Depths of Water, Latitude, Bearings and Di≈øtances from Place to Place, the Setting and Flowing of Tydes, with Directions for the knowing of any Place; and how to Harbour a Ship in the ≈øame with Safety.
With Directions for Coming into the CHANNEL between ENGLAND and FRANCE.
By Captain GREENVILE COLLINS Hydrographer in Ordinary to the KING and QUEENS most Excellent Maje≈øties.
LONDON: Printed by Freeman Collins, and are to be Sold by Richard Mount Book≈øeller, at the Po≈øtern on Tower-Hill. 1693.

figure.p: HONI SOIT QVI MALY PENSE
IE MAIN TIENDRAY
Great Britains Coasting Pylot BEING A NEW SURVEY OF THE Sea Coast By Capt. GREENVILE COLLINS HYDROGRAPHER to their MAJESTYS 1693.

div.p: Sold by Richard Mount at the Postern on Great Towerhill LONDON

TO HIS SACRED MAJESTY WILLIAM III. OF Great Britain, France, and Ireland KING, THIS SURVEY of the Sea-Coa≈øt OF GREAT BRITAIN IS MOST HUMBLY DEDICATED and PRESENTED BY YOUR MAJESTY'S MOST FAITHFUL SUBJECT AND SERVANT, Greenvile Collins.

figure.figDesc: royal blazon or coat of arms
figure.head: W R M R
figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

opener.signed: William R. WILLIAM and MARY, by the Grace of God, King and Queen of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defenders of the Faith, &c.
opener.salute: To all to whom the≈øe Pre≈øents ≈øhall come, Greeting.

div.p:
Whereas We are humbly Informed, That our Tru≈øty and Welbeloved Servant, Captain Greenvile Collins, Our HYDOGRAPHER, hath for ≈øeveral Years past, with great Pains and Expence, made a Survey of the Sea-Coa≈øt, which will be of great ∆≤≈øe and Advantage for the Safety of Navigation, and now being about to publi≈øh the ≈øame, under the Title of GREAT BRITAIN'S COASTING PILOT, hath humbly be≈øought ∆≤s to grant him Our Royal Licence for the ≈øole Printing and Publi≈øhing thereof, We have thought fit to conde≈øcend to that his Request, and We do accordingly hereby grant Our Royal Licence and Priviledge, unto the ≈øaid Captain Greenvile Collins, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, and A≈ø≈øigns, for the ≈øole Printing and Publi≈øhing the afore≈øaid Survey, under the Name and Title of GREAT BRITAIN'S COASTING PILOT, as afore≈øaid, for the Term of Fourteen Years, to be Computed from the Day of the fir≈øt ≈øetting forth of the ≈øame. And Our Royal Will and Plea≈øure is, and We do hereby Require and Command, That during the ≈øaid Term of Fourteen Years, no Per≈øon or Per≈øons what≈øoever, being our Subjects, do pre≈øume to Imprint, Engrave, or Publi≈øh, or cau≈øe to be Imprinted, Engraven, or Publi≈øhed the ≈øame, or any part thereof, or to Epitomize the ≈øame, and Imprint, Engrave, or Publi≈øh it, or any part thereof under the ≈øame, or any other Title or Name what≈øoever, or to ≈øell the ≈øame, or to Import into our Kingdom of England,
any Copies thereof Imprinted in any Parts beyond the Seas, upon pain of the Lo≈øs and Forfeiture of all Copies ≈øo Imprinted, Sold or Imported, contrary to the Tenor of this our Royal Licence, and of ≈øuch other Penalties, as the Laws and Statutes of this Our Realm will inflict, without the Knowledge Licence, and Con≈øent of him the ≈øaid Captain Greenvile Collins, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators, or A≈ø≈øigns; And Our further Will and Plea≈øure, is, That the Ma≈øter, Wardens, and A≈ø≈øi≈øtants of the Company of Stationers, in Our City of LONDON, do take due Notice hereof, and cau≈øe the ≈øame to be Entered in their Regi≈øter; And that if Occa≈øion requires, they be Aiding and A≈ø≈øi≈øting unto the ≈øaid Captain Greenvile Collins, his Executors, Admini≈øtrators or A≈ø≈øigns, in Searching for and Seizing any Plate or Plates, Print or Prints, or Copies, or Epitomies of the ≈øame, or any part thereof.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Ken≈øington the 22th Day of February, 1691/2. in the Fourth Year of our Reign.

div.head: The High and Mighty STATES of HOLLAND's PRIVILEDGE TO Captain Greenvile Collins 1692.
div.p:
DE Staten van Hollandt en We≈øtvrie≈ølandt: Doen te weten. Al≈øoo ons vertoont is by Greenvile Collins, Capiteyn van het Jaght van Sijne Koninglijke Maje≈øteyt van Groot Brittagne, ende des≈øelfs Hydrogrifus. Dat den Suppliant den tijd van twaelf jaren, naar den anderen met groote naar≈øtigheyt, doende was gewee≈øt, om een Boeck van veelderhande Caarten te practi≈øeren en op te ≈øtellen, van alle de Zeeku≈øten, Eylanden, Havens, Landen, Ondiepten, ende verdere gelegentheden van de Zee ontrent Engelandt, Schotlandt en Yrlandt met den aankleven van dien, by hem geintituleert, De Nieuwe Piloot van Groot Brittagne, het welke veel bequamer en di≈øtinctelijker was, voor alle Schippers, Pilooten en Zeevarende Per≈øoonen, dan voor henen; Dat den Suppliant daar toe veel moeyten en ko≈øten hadde aangewent, ≈øijnde de≈øelve ten reguarde van de voorgaande Caarten van de voor≈øz Zeeku≈øten, een heel nieuw en klaar werk, noyt te voren ≈øoodanig ge≈øien of uytgegeven, gelijk, uyt de voor≈øz Caarten oogen≈øchijnlijk en klaar konde, ge≈øien en aangewe≈øen worden, ≈øijnde den Suppliant van voornemen, 't ≈øelve Caarte-Boek (onder Gods hulpe) binnen den tijt van ≈øes Maanden eer≈øtkomende te laten drucken en uytgeven, ≈øoo in Engelandt in die Taal, als alhier in on≈øen Lande in de Nederduyt≈øche Tael, omme by de Zeevarende Per≈øoonen alhier te Lande mede geemployeert te werden, als haar mede ≈øeer nodig ≈øijnde: Derhalve keerde hy Suppliant hem tot Ons ootmoedelijk ver≈øoekende, dat wy hem Suppliant, ≈øijne Erven en Nakomelingen, voor den tijd van 15 eer≈øt achter een volgende jaren geliefde te verlenen Octroy, comme in den voorn. on≈øen Lande alleen te mogen laten drucken, uytgeven en verkoopen, het voor≈øz Caarte-Boek, genaamt de Nieuwe Piloot van Groot Brittagne, in ≈øoodanige Talen, Formaet, en met ≈øulke de≈øcriptie, uytlegginde en Regi≈øters, als hem Suppliant goet duncken ≈øoude, en dat op ≈øeekere groote poene by ons tegens de Contraventeurs van dien te ≈øtatueren, en hem daar van te
verleenen Octroy in debita forma. SOO IS'T; Dat wy de ≈øake en't ver≈øoek voor≈øz overgemerckt hebbende ende genegen we≈øende ter bede van den Suppliant uyt on≈øe rechte Weten≈øchap, Souvrayne Macht en Authoryteyt, den Suppliant, ≈øijne Erven en Nakomelingen gecon≈øenteert, geaccordeert geoctroyeert hebben con≈øenteren, accorderen en octroyeren mits de≈øen, dat hy geduerende den tijdt van vijftien eer≈øt achter eenvolgende jaren, het voor≈øz Caarte-boek genaamt De Nieuwe Piloot van Groot Brittagne, binnen den voorn. on≈øen Lande alleen ≈øal mogen laten drucken, uytgeven en verkoopen; verbiedende daarom allen ende eenen ygelijken het ≈øelve Caarte-boek in 't geheel ofte deel in eenigerhande formaet, en met ≈øulke di≈øcriptie, uytlegginge en Regi≈øters, en Talen, naar te drucken, ofte elders naargedrukt binnen den voorn. on≈øen Lande te brengen, uyt te geven ofte te verkoopen, op verbeurte van alle de naargedrukte, ingebrachte ofte verkochte Exemplaren, ende een boete van drie hondert guldens daar en boven te verbeuren, te appliceren een derde part voor den Officier die de calange doen ≈øal, een derde part voor den armen der plaat≈øe daar het ca≈øus voor vallen ≈øal, en het re≈øterende derde part voor den Suppliant. Ende dat hy gehouden ≈øal zijn, een Exemplaar van't voor≈øz Caarte-boek gebonden, en wel geconditioneert te brengen in de Bibliotheeck van on≈øe Univer≈øiteyt tot Leyden, ende daar af behoorlijkt te doenblijcken, op poene van het effect van de≈øen te verlie≈øen. Ende ten eyende den Suppliant de≈øen on≈øen Con≈øente en Octroye moge genieten als naar behooren. La≈øten wy allen en eenen ygelijken die 't aangaan mag, dat ≈øy den Suppliant van den innehouden van de≈øen, doen, laten, en gedogen, ru≈øtelijk, vredelijk en volkenomtlije genieten en gebruyken, ce≈ø≈øerende alle belet ter contrarie.

closer.dateline: Gedaan in den Hage onder on≈øen grooten Zegele, hier aan doen hangen den 28 Maart in 't Jaerons Heeren en Zaligmakers duy≈øent ≈øes hondert een-en t'negentigh.
closer.signed: vt. A. HEINSIUS, Ter Ordonnantie vande Staten Simon van Beaumont.

div.head: TO THE MASTER, WARDENS and ASSISTANTS OF THE TRINITY-HOUSE OF Deptford-Strond.
div.p: WHEN first His Maje≈øty King CHARLES the Second, was plea≈øed to make Choice of me for Surveying the Sea-Coa≈øt, I then, as in Duty bound (being a younger Brother) did acquaint you with it, and most humbly laid the Propo≈øals before you; whereupon you were plea≈øed not only to approve of them, but did mo≈øt bountifully Advance towards the Charge of the WORK, which being now fini≈øhed, with all Submi≈ø≈øion and Gratitude, I a≈ø≈øume the boldne≈øs to pre≈øent the≈øe Effects of my Seven Years Indu≈øtry to your Protection and Patronage.

If at any Time there ≈øhould be made new Di≈øcoveries of any Rocks or Shelves, that are not yet known; or that Sands ≈øhall change their Situation (as often they do) I ≈øhall be ready by your Advice and Commands (by God's Ble≈ø≈øing) to make a further Progre≈øs in this Survey.

I could heartily wi≈øh that it might be ≈øo ordered by your Corporation, that all Ma≈øters of Ships, both u≈øing forreign and home Voyages, might be incouraged to bring you in their Journals, and a Per≈øon appointed to In≈øpect them, which would be a great Improvement of Navigation, by imparting their Ob≈øervations and Di≈øcoveries of the true Form and Pro≈øpect of the Sea-Cao≈øt,
with all Harbours, Rivers, Bays, I≈ølands, Creeks, Sands, and Rocks, and other dangerous Places, with the Settings and Flowings of Tydes, and Currants, with the Variation of the Compa≈øs; by which means, in a few years, we might have much more exact Sea-Charts and Maps; and for want of ≈øuch a Method, we have lo≈øt many Excellent Di≈øcoveries, to the unaccountable lo≈øs of Navigation.

And that tho≈øe Per≈øons that make and ≈øell Sea-Charts and Maps, were not allowed to alter them upon the ≈øingle Report of Mariners, but with your Approbation, by which means our Sea-Charts would be more Correct, and the common Scandal of their badne≈øs removed, that God may pro≈øper all your Generous and Charitable ∆≤ndertakings; which that they may always ≈øucceed the greate≈øt Advantage po≈ø≈øible of all their Maje≈øties Subjects, is the con≈øtant hearty Wi≈øh and Prayer of

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble and mo≈øt obedient Servant and younger Brother, GREENVILE COLLINS.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER. To my Fellow Mariners of GREAT BRITAIN.
div.p: HIS mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty King CHARLES the Second, who was a great Lover of the Noble Art of NAVIGATION, finding that there were no Sea-Charts or Maps of the≈øe Kingdoms but what were Dutch, and Copies from them, and tho≈øe very erroneous, his Maje≈øty out of his great Zeal for the better Improvement of Navigation, was pleas'd in the Year 1681. to give me the Command of a Yatch for the making this Survey; in which Service I ≈øpent Seven years time.

The Intent of this Survey is only to give Directions to Mariners to Sail along≈øt the Coa≈øt of Great Britain, and how to carry a Ship into any Harbour, River, Port, Road, Bay, or Creek with ≈øafety, and how to avoid all Dangers known.

It ≈øometimes happens, and that too frequently, that when Ships which have made long and dangerous Voyages, and are come home richly Laden, have been ≈øhipwrack't on their Native Coa≈øt, whereby both Merchants, Owners and Mariners have been impoveri≈øh't. All our Neighbours will acknowledge that no Nation abounds more with skilful and experienced Seamen than our own, none meeting a Danger with more Courage or Bravery; none taking more Care, or u≈øe more Circum≈øpection to prevent it, or are more laborious to overcome it: But we cannot expect that the Ma≈øter and Mates of every Ship ≈øhould be acquainted with all the Coa≈øts and Harbours of Great Britain, into which they may be accidentally obliged to Enter. Sometimes it happens, that in long Voyages the Ma≈øter and the mo≈øt knowing Men die, and the Ship is brought into ≈øight of Land by tho≈øe who have skill enough to conduct the Ship at Sea, but are wholly unacquainted
with the Coa≈øts and Harbours, or having but little Knowledge, dare not tru≈øt to it; in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, and to ≈øuch Per≈øons, this Survey will ≈øerve in the room of a Pilot.

As many Ships are lo≈øt by Ignorance and Negligence, as by ≈øtre≈øs of Weather, ≈øo a Ma≈øter of a Ship hath a very great Charge, and ought to be a ≈øober Man, as well as a skilful Mariner: All helps of Art, Care, and Circum≈øpection are to be u≈øed by him, that the Lives of Mariners (the mo≈øt u≈øeful of their Maje≈øties Subjects at this Juncture) and the Fortunes of hone≈øt Merchants under his Care, may be pre≈øerved. To ≈øupply the Defects of which, I have been Employed by their Maje≈øties Predece≈ø≈øors, and Encouraged by Ingenious and Noble Benefactors; and as I have hitherto made it my Bu≈øine≈øs to make tho≈øe true Figures of our Coa≈øts and Harbours ≈øo to ≈øerve my Country, I ≈øhall not be wanting to give them ≈øuch Additions and Amendments as I ≈øhall find hereafter needful: Wi≈øhing you always happy and ≈øucce≈øsful Voyages, and ≈øafe Returns, with Pro≈øperity to the Nation and its Forces by Sea and Land, that as we have been hitherto, ≈øo we may even be at home Soveraigns of the Seas, and Umpiers of the Differences betwixt our Neighbours abroad, which as it is every good man's Wi≈øh, ≈øo is it the con≈øtant hearty Prayer of
