div.head: GREAT BRITAINS COASTING PILOT.
The Explanation of ≈øome Marks in the Sea-Charts.

list.item: THE Depths of Water are all put down at Low-water on Spring Tydes, as you may ≈øee in the Chart going into Foy, Number 17. there you will find that the lea≈øt water going into that place is three Fathom. But where you find a Line drawn between two Figures, as in the Margent, which is u≈øed no where but at ≈øuch places as there is not three Fathom at Low-water. As for Example; At the going into Rye, as you may ≈øee in the Chart, Number 8. there on the Bar you find the Figure 4 above the Line, which ≈øheweth that there is four Fathom at High-water: Then under the Line there is the figure 1, which ≈øheweth that there is but one Fathom at Low-water on a Spring Tide.
list.label: 18/6f
list.item: But for more exactne≈øs, the depths of water on ≈øome Bars, where there is but little water, there the depths are ≈øet down in Feet at High and Low-water; and to be known from Fathoms, there is the Letter f plac'd by them, as in the Margent, as you may ≈øee in the Chart going into Exmouth, Number 14. there you find, as in the Margent, that there is 18 foot at High-water, and 6 foot at Low-water.

Where you ≈øhall ≈øee a Half-moon, as in the Margent, plac'd by or on any Rock or Sand, it ≈øignifieth that ≈øuch a Rock or Sand is to be ≈øeen at the Half-tide; that is, from half Ebb to half Flood, as you may ≈øee in the Chart of Falmouth, Numb. 18. There is a Rock in the Harbours mouth, call'd Falmouth Rock, and hath a Pole on it to ≈øhew where it is overflowed, and by it you will ≈øee a Half-moon.
list.label: ‚Üí
list.item: Where you ≈øhall ≈øee an Arrow, as in the Margent, it ≈øheweth that the Tide of Flood, or part of it, running the ≈øame way the Arrow pointeth, as you may ≈øee in the Chart of the I≈øle of Wight and Che≈øter-Bar.

div.p: It may be expected that I ≈øhould have given Directions for Sailing from the River of Thames over the Flats into the Downs; and likewi≈øe from the River Thames down the Swin and the King's Channel, and ≈øo into the Downs: But upon con≈øideration that the≈øe Places are under the Care of Pilots, and for the con≈øtant ≈øupply of them, the Trinity-Hou≈øe of Deptford Strond have taken care that there be a ≈øufficient number of them, both for great and ≈ømall Ships, I have put the Sands down in the Sand-Chart from the Thames into the Downs, and from the Thames to the Buoy of the Gunfleet, as they were mo≈øt carefully ≈øurveyed by Trinity-Hou≈øe, and all the re≈øt of the Charts is my own Survey.

div.head: Directions to Sail from the Downs to the We≈øtward.
Dunginne≈øs.
div.p:
FRom the South Foreland to Dunginne≈øs, the Cour≈øe South we≈øt by ≈øouth ≈øix Leagues. Dunginne≈øs is a low Beachy-point, on which is a Light-hou≈øe; this place is very bold, you may keep within nine and ten
Fathom of it clo≈øe by the ≈øhoar. There is good Anchoring on the Ea≈øt ≈øide with a we≈øterly wind, if the wind be contrary, and that you ≈øhould turn to windward from Dover to the Ne≈øs, there lieth a Sand called the Riprap Riprap. in the Midway between Dover and the French ≈øhoar. The ≈øhoale≈øt part of it beareth from Dover ≈øouth, and ≈øouth by ea≈øt, and from Calis Cliffs we≈øt by ≈øouth. It lyeth in length North ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt, both ends pointing the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt in length about four Leagues, but very narrow; there is on it at Low-water fifteen foot. There lieth another ≈ømall Sand between this and Dover, called the Gunman-Sand, where is but twelve foot at Low-water, and lieth from the South Foreland South about five or ≈øix miles, and is not above two miles over; it lieth North ea≈øt and South we≈øt; you have five and ≈øix Fathem clo≈øe to it all round, and twenty Fathom between it and the Riprap.

div.head: Rye.
div.p:
To the we≈øtward of Dunginne≈øs lieth Rye Harbour; it is a Bar-place, but the water ri≈øeth three and four Fathom. On the ea≈øt ≈øide, going in, there are two white Beacons on the Beach, which you keep together till you bring the Leadings Marks together, then run in. When you are in the Harbour you will have no le≈øs than fifteen and ≈øixteen foot at Low-water, as you may ≈øee in the Chart, Number 8. where the going in is ≈øo plainly demon≈øtrated, that you need have no other Directions. As you Sail from Rye to Beachy, keep not near the ≈øhoar, when you come thwart of Pem≈øey;
Pem≈øey Shoal. for there lieth a ≈ømall Stone-bank on which is but eleven and twelve foot at Low-water. The Mark for it is Beachy North we≈øt, and Pem≈øey Ca≈øtle North half ea≈øt.

div.head: Beachy-Head.
div.p: From Dunginne≈øs to Beachy-Head the Cour≈øe is We≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt about nine Leagues. Beachy is a high ≈øteep white Chalk Cliff: To the we≈øtward of which lieth the ≈øeven white Chalkey Cliffs, called the Seven Cliffs, Seven Cliffs. and are very remarkable. Some ≈øay there lieth a Shoal right off of Beachy-Head, but I could not find it; however, it may be a ≈ømall Spot, and hard to find, therefore the be≈øt way is not to come too near it.

div.head: Cuckmore Haven.
div.p: Cuckmore Haven lieth four miles to the we≈øtward of Beachy-Head, and is a Bar Harbour, not having above ≈øix foot at Low-water, and thirteen and fourteen at High-water. When you are in, you lie dry at Low-water. This place ≈øometimes by ≈øtorms is ≈øtopt up with the Beach, and by great Land-floods is opened again.

div.head: New-Haven.
div.p: New-Haven is another ≈ømall Bar-place, and lieth eight or nine miles to the we≈øtward of Beachy, only fit for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: Shorum.
div.p: Shorum lieth between ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues to the we≈øtward of Beachy, and is a Bar-place; but better than Cuckmore and New-Haven: The Bar often ≈øhifts. There are Beacons to run in by: when you are in, there is nine foot at Low-water. Here are many good Ships built.

div.head: Bright-Hemp≈øton.
div.p: Bright-Hemp≈øton is a Town that ≈øtandeth by the Sea-≈øide on a Beach. There are many Ve≈ø≈øels belong to it, which they heap up with Crabs on the dry Beach. This place lieth four miles to the ea≈øtward of Shorum.

div.head: Arundel.
div.p: Arundel lieth ten Leagues to the we≈øtward of Beachy, and four ≈øhort Leagues to the we≈øtward of Shorum, and is a Tide-Haven: where at High-water and Half-flood Ships go in, keeping the We≈øt-≈øide aboard; and being in, may there ride afloat. I might have ≈øaid more of the≈øe Bar-Harbours, but I leave it to Coa≈øters, and do not recommend it to Strangers, they being Harbours of little Trade or Re≈øort.

div.head: Ea≈øt-barrow-heads.
div.p:
From Beachy to the I≈øle of Wight the Cour≈øe is We≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt eighteen Leagues. When you Sail from Beachy to the I≈øle of Wight, you mu≈øt have a great care of the Ea≈øt-barrow-heads and the Owers; which lye ≈øeven Leagues to the Ea≈øtward of the I≈øle of Wight, and four Leagues from the ≈øhoar. The Ea≈øt barrow-head lieth from Arundel
≈øouth by we≈øt four Leagues, on which is but ten foot at Low-water, and is about three miles in length ≈øouth and north, and about two miles broad ea≈øt and we≈øt. A mile north by ea≈øt from this Bank lieth another ≈øhoal called the Little Ea≈øt-barrow-head, and is about two miles in length north and ≈øouth, and a mile broad, having but nine foot at Low-water, and beareth north we≈øt from Chiche≈øter Church-Spire, and two miles to the northward of the≈øe lye a ≈ømall parcel of Rocks, call'd Kingman-Rocks, and lye four miles ≈øouth by we≈øt from the going into Arundel. You have five Fathom between them and the ≈øhoar.

div.head: Owers.
div.p: The Owers lye ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt from Chiche≈øter Spire, and four Leagues from the ≈øhoar, and about four long Leagues or five Leagues ea≈øt from Bendridge Point on the I≈øle of Wight; there length is north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt, about three Leagues, and about three miles broad in the middle, and narrow at each end, and dry at Low-water. There lieth another ≈øhoal on the in≈øide of this, the north end of it dries at Low-water: Between which and the ≈øhoar is another Shoal lying in length as the Owers do, called the Mixens, and lieth from Sel≈øey Point about two miles ≈øouth. There is a Channel between the Owers and the Mixens, but it being of no u≈øe but to tho≈øe that are very well acquainted, I will not give any Directions to Sail through them, nor within them. There lye ≈øome other Banks within them, which I forbear to ≈øpeak of them. The only and chief end of my bu≈øine≈øs is to give good Directions how to avoid the≈øe ≈øhoals, that have proved ≈øo fatal to many Ships. There are very good Marks to avoid them, if you keep Dunno≈øe we≈øt, you run a good brith without them; there is twelve Fathom water clo≈øe to them; keep in eighteen Fathom and you will not be in any danger of them.How Ships are lo≈øt on the Owers. The great rea≈øon why ≈øo many Ships have fallen in on the≈øe Shoals, is the great Indraught of the Tide ≈øetting ≈øtrong into St. Helens eight hours or more; the latter part of the Flood ≈øets into St. Helens. My advice is, That when you are near this place in the night time, or thick weather, to be very careful, and keep your Lead well: In little Wind or Calms you ≈øhall be drawn in here to admiration, by the ≈øtrong Indraught, which if you find, Anchor in time.

div.head: Chiche≈øter.
div.p: To the ea≈øtward of the Owers is the going into Chiche≈øter, and very difficult; therefore I advi≈øe none but them that are acquainted to go in there without a Pilot.

div.head: Directions for Sailing into the Ea≈øt end of the I≈øle of Wight, called St. Helens.
div.p:
COming from the Ea≈øtward, come no nearer the Owers then eighteen Fathom water, and keep the Culver Cliff or Swan Cliff we≈øt north we≈øt, which is a high ≈øteep white Chalkey Cliff, as you may ≈øee in the making of the Lands, Number 35. and is two miles from Benbridge Point, which is the ea≈øtermo≈øt Point of the I≈øland. Being come within a League of the Swan Cliff, or thereabouts, then ≈øteer in for St. Helens, and have a care of the Spit that lieth away to the ea≈øtward from Benbridge Point; when the Swan Cliff is hid behind Benbridge Point, then are you within it, as you may ≈øee in the Chart, Number 9. you may run over this Spit in five and 6 Fathom water. If you will Anchor in St. Helens Road,St. Helens Road. bring St. Helens Church we≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt, and Anchor in five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, or eight Fathom water. There is a ≈ømall Ow≈øey Bank in St. Helens Bay, which hath but fourteen foot at Low-water on it, and is called the Warner, which beareth N. E. from St. Helens Church. Being in St. Helens Road, and that you would go in for the Spithead, you will ≈øee a leading Mark, which is Gilkicker, a white Tower by the Sea-≈øide and Stoke-Church, one in the other; but the be≈øt of the Channel, between the Hor≈øe and Nomans Land, is to keep the ≈øaid Church ju≈øt open to the ≈øouthward of Gilkicker, and Anchor at the Spithead, Spithead. bring the ≈ømall Village called Ryde by the Sea-≈øide on the I≈øle of Wight to bear we≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt, and Gilkicker north we≈øt, then you may Anchor in the be≈øt of the Road, at the Spithead, To Anchor at the Spithead. which is a very good Road, and clean Ground, where the Royal Navy many times ride. The Hor≈øe Marks for the Hor≈øe. is hard Ground, and in ≈øome places not above ≈øeven foot water at Low-water; when the great white Patch on Port≈ømouth Down is on ≈øouth Sea-Ca≈øtle, then are you within it; keep Port≈ømouth Church-≈øteeple on a ≈ømall Redoubt which is like a Dove-hou≈øe, and ≈øtandeth on the Ea≈øt-≈øide of Port≈ømouth: the≈øe two in one will carry you clo≈øe by the
Hor≈øe in five and ≈øix Fathom water. The ea≈øtward part of this great Bank is called the Dean. Dean. When the Wind-mill on the I≈øle of Wight beareth ≈øouth we≈øt by we≈øt, then are you abrea≈øt the Buoy of the Hor≈øe.

div.head: Nomans Land.
div.p: The Thwart-Mark for the Spit of Nomans Land, Nomans Land. is to bring the Wind-mill on the I≈øle of Wight between the ≈øouth we≈øt and the ≈øouth we≈øt by we≈øt, then will the ≈øaid Mill be ju≈øt over a ≈øquare Field by the Water-≈øide; which ≈øaid Mill, if you keep ≈øight of it, will carry you clear of Nomans Land; but if the Mill is hid by the Land, then will you run aground on the ≈øaid Spit. This Mark will carry you up into Cowes Road: But for Anchoring in Stoaks-Bay, going up into Hamton water, or to Sail up to Yarmouth, I refer you to the Chart, which is ≈øo plain, that there needs no Directions. If you have occa≈øion to turn from St. Helens Whento turn into St. Helens. into the Spithead, have a care of Nomans Land, which is ≈øteep too; you will have twelve Fathom, and next Ca≈øt a ≈øhoar; but on the Hor≈øe you may ≈øtand into eight or nine Fathom, and turn the Church a little open of each ≈øide of Gilkicker. There are ≈øeveral other Marks in the Chart, which I refer you to, that I will not mention, as being needle≈øs. All within the I≈øle of Wight is good ≈øafe Anchoring.

Being in Yarmouth Road, and that you would Sail out of the Needles, How to Sail out of the Needles. ≈øteer away for Hur≈øt Ca≈øtle, which place is very ≈øteep; being pa≈øt the Ca≈øtle, ≈øteer away for the Needles, which are ≈øharp white Rocks; giving a birth to ≈øome Rocks that lye off from the I≈øland ≈øide, in the fair way between the Ca≈øtle and the Needles, you mu≈øt keep clo≈øe to the Needles. The Tyde of Ebb ≈øetteth on the Shingles, which are hard Stones. The Flood ≈øetteth on the Needles.

To Sail into the Needles; How to Sail into the Needles. you will know the going in by the high white Land which is the we≈øt end of the I≈øle of Wight; run boldly in with the Land, till you ≈øee the Needle You may Sail within a Ships length of the Needles. Rocks, and then keep clo≈øe to them, ob≈øerving the Tydes, as in the Directions coming out. Note, that there is a ≈øtrong Indraught that ≈øets in at the Needles, Indraught into the Needles. and into Pool; which Indraught hath hauld many Ships into Fre≈øh-water Bay. But I think it, and I am very ≈øure, that no Ship can run a≈øhoar in Fre≈øh-water Bay, if they did but mind the Lead; the neglect of which hath been the lo≈øs of many Ship. Keep in five and twenty and thirty Fathom water, and you need not fear the Indraught of the Wight.

div.head: Chri≈øt-Church.
div.p: Chri≈øt-Church Chri≈øt Church. is a Bar-place, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels run in at High-water. This place lieth ≈øeven miles to the we≈øtward of Hur≈øt Castle.

div.head: Pool.
div.p: Pool Pool. is a Bar-Haven, and lyeth five Leagues to the we≈øtward of the Needles, or I≈øle of Wight, where Ships Sail in with a High-tyde. There is good Anchoring in Studland-Bay, Studland Bay. which lieth between the Entrance of Pool Haven and Studland Point; and Sandwich-Bay lyeth between Studland Point and Peverly Point, where is good Anchoring for we≈øterly Winds. I have not as yet ≈øurvey'd Pool Harbour, but 'tis intended God-willing.

From Peverly Point to the we≈øtward the Land is high, and is called the High-land of St. Albans. About two Leagues or more to the we≈øtward of Peverly PointFoul Ground & Shoal-water between Peverly Point and Waymouth. is Kembridge Ledge, and lyeth off from the ≈øhoar ≈øouth by ea≈øt into the Sea a mile and half off, and hath at that di≈øtance but ≈øix foot at Low-water, and three quarters of a mile off thirteen foot, and a mile off four Fathom. There is another Ledge that lyeth right off from St. Albans-head, about three quarters of a mile off ≈øhoar, and hath but twelve foot at Low-water, and lyeth between Kembredge Ledge and Peverly Point.

div.head: Lulworth.
div.p: Four Leagues to the we≈øtward of Peverly Point is a ≈ømall Cove called Lulworth, Lulworth. where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels may Ride.

div.head: Portland Road.
div.p:
Portland RoadP ‚Ä¢ rt ‚Ä¢ and R ‚Ä¢ ad. is a mo≈øt excellent good Road for we≈øterly and ≈øoutherly Winds, very good holding clear Ground. As you Sail into Portland Road, you mu≈øt have a care of a Shoal called the Shambles, Shambles which hath but fourteen foot water at Low-water, as you may ≈øee in the Draught of Portland, Number 12. Bring Waymouth Ca≈øtle ju≈øt on the ea≈øtward part of Portland, and that will bring you ju≈øt on the edge of it in three Fathom and a half; then will the Bill of
Portland bear we≈øt by north: But if you keep the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle and Point a Sails breadth open, it will carry you clear. You may Anchor in Portland Road from five Fathom to ten Fathom, bringing the ea≈øtward part of Portland to bear ≈øouth and ≈øouth by ea≈øt, and ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt. You may Sail clo≈øe by the Land of Portland from the Bill into the Road.

div.head: Waymouth.
div.p: Waymouth Waymouth is a Bar-Haven, where at Low-water there is but ≈øix foot, and the Tydes ri≈øe but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot on a Spring; within the Bar is a ≈ømall Hole, where there is nine foot at Low-water: and tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that lye by the Keys before the Town, lye dry at Low-water. There is good Riding in Waymouth Road.

div.head: Race of Portland.
div.p: The Race of Portland Race of Portland. is a great Ripling of the Tydes, cau≈øed by the unevenne≈øs of the Ground at the bottom, called Overfalls; and when the Sea is high, and the Tydes ≈øtrong, it breaketh in great Seas, and one that is a ≈øtranger would think that there were ≈øhoal-water. This Ripling or Race beginneth a mile to the we≈øtward of the Bill, about a mile and a half or two mile off; and runneth to the ea≈øtward as far as St. Albans.
There is good Anchoring to the we≈øtward of Portland for ea≈øterly Winds.

div.head: Lime.
div.p: Lime, Lime. a ≈ømall Peer called Lime-Cobb, where Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground at Low-water. This Place lyeth ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues to the we≈øtward of Portland.

div.head: Exmouth-Bar.
div.p: Exmouth-Bar Exmouth. lyeth fifteen Leagues to the we≈øtward of Portland, and three or four Leagues to the northward of Torbay; the going into this Place is very narrow, having Rocks on the ea≈øt ≈øide, and Sand on the we≈øt ≈øide. At Low-water there is but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot on the Bar; but at High-water ≈øixteen and eighteen foot water. Here are always Pilots ready to come off; and I advi≈øe no man to venter into that Place without a Pilot. Being over the Bar, there is a Place called Star-Cro≈øs, Star Cro≈øs. where Ships commonly ride afloat in ten and twelve foot at Low-water. But ≈øuch Ships as go up to the Town of Top≈øham Top≈øham. lye aground at Low-water, from whence their Goods is carried up in Lighters through Sluces to the City of Exon. Exon.

div.head: Tinmouth.
div.p: Tinmouth Tinmouth. lyeth between Torbay and Exmouth, and is a Tyde-Haven where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels u≈øe; and had formerly a great Trade to Newfoundland.

div.head: Torbay.
div.p: Torbay Torbay. is a large Place, very good and clear ground to Anchor in, e≈øpecially for we≈øterly and ≈øoutherly Winds, provided they be not to the ea≈øtward of the South. You may Anchor ≈øo far, as to bring the Berry ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt. Here are two Peers in this Bay where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground, Brixham on the ≈øouth ≈øide, and Tarkey on the north ≈øide. Here the Royal Navy rides in ≈øafety.

div.head: Dartmouth.
div.p: Dartmouth Dartmouth. lyeth two Leagues to the we≈øtward of the Berry or Torbay; the going in is very narrow between two high Lands; in the narrow it is but ju≈øt a Cables length over. On the we≈øt ≈øide is a Ca≈øtle, and on the ea≈øt ≈øide a Block-hou≈øe. The going in and out at this Place is very dangerous, except the Wind blow right in, which are ≈øoutherly Winds: for if the winds be either ea≈øterly or we≈øterly, then the high Lands which lye off each ≈øide, cau≈øe Overflows and Calms, ≈øometimes blowing in, and pre≈øently right out again, which hinders a Ship in turning in and out, by putting them a≈øtays unawares. There are always Boats ready to come off, which are good Boats to row, and are called Two-boats, and are very ≈øerviceable in towing ≈øhips in and out, and to tow them a-≈øtays; without which Boats it is very dangerous going in and out. The northerly Winds blow right out, and the ≈øoutherly Winds right in; but the ea≈øterly and we≈øterly Winds blow with Flaws and Calms in and out. Being in, it is a mo≈øt excellent good Harbour, and can contain the Navy Royal.
There is good Anchoring without the Harbours mouth in the Road, called Dartmouth-Range. Dartmouth Range.

From Darmouth to the Start Start. there is a Bay, and the ≈øhoar bould, only there lyeth a ≈ømall Rock half a mile or more off of the Start. The Start is a low ragged Point ri≈øing from the Sea high into the Land.

From the Start to the Praul Praul. the Cour≈øe is we≈øt north we≈øt, about a little League; and
from the Praul to the Boulthead we≈øt north we≈øt, two miles. Between the≈øe two Heads is the going into Salcomb, Salcomb. which is a Bar-Harbour, on which there is nine foot at Low-water, and four Fathom at High-water, and more. Being in, there is very good Anchoring in the Bagg at three, four, and five Fathom water at Low-water. The Boulthead is very high Land. The Entrance into Salcomb is very narrow between the Old Ca≈øtle and the Black Stone, being not above three quarters of a Cables length over, as you may ≈øee in the Chart, Number 6. The Block Stone ≈øhoweth at Low-water, or the la≈øt quarter Ebb. It floweth here at Full and Change at ≈øix of the Clock.

div.head: Plymouth.
div.p: Plymouth Pl ‚Ä¢ mouth. lyeth between the Start and Ramhead, where is a large Sound, called Plymouth Sound, Plymouth Sound. and lyeth a mile to the ea≈øtward of the Ramhead. Here is a ≈øunk Rock in the Sound, called the Shovel, where is but ≈øixteen foot water at Low-water, as you may ≈øee in the Chart of Plymouth, Number 16. the we≈øt ≈øide of it is the be≈øt ≈øailing in. The common MarkMarks to Anchor in the Sound. for to Anchor in the be≈øt Ground in the Sound, is to bring Mount Edgcom-hou≈øe ju≈øt open, and Withy-hedge right up and down, as you may ≈øee in the Chart on the ea≈øt ≈øide. There lyeth another Rock near the Shagstone, called the Tinkers-≈øhears or Swift≈øure, and hath ≈øeventeen foot at Low-water.

div.head: Catwater.
div.p: Catwater Catwater. is a good Place, where Ships ride that are bound to the we≈øtward; going in, there lyeth a Buoy again≈øt Mount Batten; you Sail in clo≈øe by the we≈øt ≈øide of rhe Buoy: Being in, you mu≈øt haul out a good Anchor well over to Mount Batten ≈øide; for want of ≈øo doing many Ships have drove a≈øhoar on Catdown ≈øide. There is a Place within the Cittadel and Barbigan, called Sutton Pool, Sutton-Pool. where Ships lye aground on ≈øoft Oaze at Low-water, by the Keys ≈øide before the Town of Plymouth.

div.head: Ham-Oaze.
div.p: Ham-Oaze. Ham-Oaze. is a Place where Ships ride that are bound to the ea≈øtward. To Sail into Ham-Oaze, you mu≈øt give the I≈øland a great birth, keeping in the fair way between the I≈øland and Mount Batten, till you have opened Mount Edgcomb within the I≈øland; then ≈øtand away with Mount Edgcomb between the I≈øland and the Main, giving a birth to German-Rock, which lyeth on the Starboard ≈øide going into the Narrow. You mu≈øt have a care that you do not go in here when the Tyde of Ebb is made ≈øtrong out, for it will ≈øet your Ship a≈øhoar on Mount Edgcomb ≈øide. There lyeth a Ledge off from Pa≈ø≈øage-Point going into Ham-Oaze, of which you mu≈øt have a care: being in, you may Anchor where you plea≈øe. Ju≈øt above Froward-Point is a mo≈øt excellent Dock and Yard,Kings-Dock. built for the u≈øe of the Navy. Ships may Anchor betwen the I≈øland and the main Clo≈øe under the I≈øland. Yalme-water Yalme-water. is a place where is two and three Fathom water at Low-water, but very ≈øeldom made u≈øe of; it floweth here at Full and Change ea≈øt by north.

div.head: Eddy-≈øtone.
div.p: The Eddy-≈øtone Eddy-≈øtone lyeth ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt from Plymouth-Sound; the north we≈øt part of it is above water (at a high Spring-tyde) about ≈øix or ≈øeven foot high; the north we≈øt ≈øide is bold and ≈øteep, but the ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt part of it is foul about half a mile at Low-water; there are ≈øeveral Rocks ≈øhow them≈øelves above water. This Rock lyeth from the Start we≈øt a little ≈øoutherly, and from Ram-head ≈øouth by we≈øt. A little we≈øterly, about three Leagues or rather more from Ram-head, you have twenty Fathom water clo≈øe by Ram-head; and between the Head and the Eddy-≈øtone thirty five and thirty ≈øix Fathom water; and in the Stream of the Eddy-≈øtone forty Fathom. Keep without forty Fathom water, and you cannot come foul of the Eddy-≈øtone. It is High-water here at the Stone when it is High-water at Plymouth; from the Start to the Lizard in the Offing, it floweth half Tyde,Half-tyde that is, ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt: It is half Flood at Plymouth before the Flood getteth to the ea≈øtward in the Offing.

div.head: Loo.
div.p: Ea≈øt and We≈øt-Loo Loo. are two ≈ømall Towns, which lye three Leagues to the we≈øtward of Ram-head; you may know the Place by a high I≈øland that lyeth a little to the we≈øtward of the going in to the Harbour, which is a Bar, where are many ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels and Fi≈øher-boats, which lye dry at Low-water: you have at High-water commonly ten foot going in; you may Anchor before the Town in a wild Road.

div.head: Directions for Sailing into Fowey or Foy.
div.p: FOY lyeth four Leagues north ea≈øt from the Deadman, and two miles to the we≈øtward of a great Bay called St. Blazey-Bay, Predmouth-Point being the we≈øt ≈øide of the Bay. There lyeth a Ledge of Rocks ≈øouth ea≈øt about half a mile from the ≈øaid Point, called the Canneys, and ≈øhew them≈øelves above water at half-Tyde: there is but ≈øeven and eight foot water within them at Low-water. From the≈øe Rocks to the going into Foy the ≈øhoar is bold. Keep the Deadman without the Winhead-Rock, and it will carry you clear off the Canneys.

div.head: Foy.
div.p: Foy Foy. may be very ea≈øily known, lying in between two high Lands; on the we≈øt ≈øide the going in, is an old Church and Ca≈øtle, and on the ea≈øt ≈øide the Ruins of an old Church, as you may ≈øee by the making of it in the Draught of Foy, Number 17. The going in is a Cables length over from ≈øide to ≈øide, and no danger; when you are in, you may Anchor before the Town, or run up above the Town. In the time of the Dutch War, in the Year 1666. there was above ≈øixty Sail of Virginia Ships put into this Harbour. This Place lyeth north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt in and out, which makes it a better Outlet to the we≈øtward then Plymouth or Falmouth. And whereas it hath been reported to be a Bar-Harbour, and that you cannot enter till half Tyde, I do a≈ø≈øure you that there is no le≈øs than three Fathom at Low-water at a Spring-tyde: here you may lye a≈øhoar to Wa≈øh, Tallow, ≈øtop Leeks. The Spring-tides ri≈øe and fall ≈øixteen and ≈øeventeen foot; and it is High-water here at Full and Change half an hour pa≈øt five. There is good Anchoring in the Road without the Harbour, from five to ten Fathom water, but without that Depth foul Ground.

div.head: Deadman.
div.p: The Deadman Deadman. is a high Bluff-head, and lyeth ≈øouth we≈øt four Leagues from Foy, and north ea≈øt by ea≈øt ≈øeven Leagues from the Lizard, and three Leagues from Falmouth. North ea≈øt from the Deadman lyeth a big Rock above water, called the Winhead-Rock, Winhead-Rock. and lyeth three miles from the Deadman, and a mile from the neare≈øt ≈øhoar. Small Ve≈ø≈øels that are well acquainted Sail within this Rock.

div.head: St. Blazey-Bay.
div.p: Between the Deadman and Predmouth-Point, St. Blazey-Bay. by the going into Foy, is a large deep ≈øandy Bay, called St. Blazey-Bay. From the Deadman to Falmouth the Coa≈øt is bold; and clo≈øe by the ≈øhoar, between the Deadman and Falmouth, lyeth a Rock above water, called the Gull-Rock.

div.head: Directions for to Sail into Falmouth Harbour.
div.p:
Falmouth Falmouth. lyeth between the Lizard and the Deadman, and may very well be known by Pendennis Ca≈øtle, which ≈øtandeth on a Hill on the we≈øt ≈øide of the Harbours mouth, as you may ≈øee by the making of it, in the Draught of Falmouth, Numb 18. There is a Rock which lyeth in the Harbours mouth, and lyeth nearer the we≈øt ≈øhoar than the ea≈øt ≈øhoar; this Rock is called Falmouth-Rock, Falmouth-Rock. and ≈øheweth it ≈øelf above water at half-Tyde; there is a Pole plac'd on it, to ≈øhew where it lyeth when it is under water. You may Sail in and out of either ≈øide of this Rock; the ea≈øt ≈øide is the be≈øt. Being pa≈øt the Rock, and that you would Anchor in Carreck-Road, Carreck-Road. which is the Place where great Ships ride, you may Sail up in the fair way, keeping your Lead; for there is a narrow deep Channel which hath eighteen Fathom water all the way up to Carreck-Road; you may borrow on St. Mawes ≈øide in five and ≈øix Fathom water: the we≈øt ≈øide is ≈øhoal. Being pa≈øt about St. Mawes Ca≈øtle, there lyeth off from the ea≈øt ≈øhoar a ≈øandy Bank, and is very ≈øteep too, and lyeth almo≈øt half Channel over from the ea≈øt ≈øhoar. The be≈øt Anchoring in Carreck-Road is to bring St. Mawes-Ca≈øtle ea≈øt north ea≈øt, laying your ea≈øtward Anchor in eighteen Fathom, and your we≈øtward Anchor in four and five Fathom, as you think convenient. But if you would Sail up in St. Ju≈øt-Pool, which is the be≈øt Place in all the Harbour, then keep near the we≈øt ≈øhoar, or Trefu≈øis-Land, and then ≈øtand over into St. Ju≈øt-Pool, between St. Mawes Sand and the middle; you may run up by your Lead, borrowing on either ≈øide no nearer then ≈øix Fathom water more or
le≈øs, according to the bigne≈øs of your Ship. Note that you are not ≈øo ready to Sail from St. Ju≈øt, as you are from Barreck-Road.

From St. Just-Pool you may Sail to Turner-ware Point, keeping clo≈øe by the ea≈øt ≈øhoar, where you will have two Fathom at Low-water, and five at High-water. Being come up to the Point of Turner-ware, give the Point a di≈øtance to avoid a Shoal that lyeth off from it: being above the ≈øaid Point, you many Anchor any where between Turner-ware and Mopa≈øs in great ≈øafety: but ≈øuch Ve≈ø≈øels as go up to Truro Truro. take the Tyde, and there lye dry at Low-water. You may lay up a great Fleet of great Ships between Turner-ware and Mopa≈øs.

If you will Anchor before the Town of Falmouth, To anchor before the Town of Falmouth. and that your Ship draweth above twelve foot water, you mu≈øt not go over the Bar at Low-water (which lyeth between Trefu≈øes-land and Penden ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s) but mu≈øt take the Tyde with you, and Ancho ‚Ä¢ before the Town. Again≈øt the Rock is three Fathom at Low-water, and above and below it there is two Fathom and a half „Äà‚óä„Äâ Low-water. Tho≈øe Ve≈ø≈øels that go up „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Penr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
mu≈øt take the Tyde, where at Low-water they lye dry by the Keys ≈øide.

If any Ships have occa≈øion to haul a≈øhoar to wa≈øh, tallow, ≈øtop leaks, or load or unload Goods, Sir Peter Killigrew hath been at very great Charges in building a very good,A good place to load or unload. convenient and ≈øafe Mole or Peer, where are Keys with Cranes, and good Store-hou≈øes or Ware-hou≈øes, to load or unload Goods, the Ships lying by the Keys ≈øide clo≈øe by the Store-hou≈øe. Many Virginia Ships have here unloaded their Tobacco, and is very convenient for that purpo≈øe. The Tydes ri≈øe and fall here at a Spring Tyde eighteen and tweenty foot, and twelve and fourteen at a Nep-tyde. It floweth here at Full and Change five hours and a half. There is a ≈ømall Place called St. Mawes-Road, St. Mawes Road. where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels ride before St. Mawes Town in two and three Fathom at Low-water.

div.head: Manacles.
div.p: Manacles.In ≈øailing in and out at this Place, and that you come from the we≈øtward, or are bound to the we≈øtward, you mu≈øt have a care of the Manacle-Rocks which lye ≈øouth by we≈øt from the mouth of Falmouth Harbour two Leagues, ≈øome of them lye above water, and ≈øome under water, and lye about three miles ea≈øt away from the Land into the Sea. You may Sail out of Falmouth to carry your ≈øelf clear of them ≈øouth by ea≈øt; but with the Tyde of Ebb you mu≈øt ≈øteer ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth.

div.head: Helford.
div.p: Helford Helford. lyeth between Falmouth and the Manacles, it is an open Sound and lyeth we≈øt in: as you Sail in and out keep in the fair way, but more to the ≈øouth ≈øhoar than the north, the north being foul Ground ≈øome di≈øtance off. Being in, you may bring Maunan Church N. N. W. or N. W. and anchor in three Fathom and a half at low-water, and two Fathom, according as your Ship is big. A little to the ea≈øtward of Helford Town lyeth a Bar, the be≈øt of it is by the ≈øouth ≈øhoar, where is nine foot at low-water, and the ≈øame depth before the Town, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye. The going in to this Place may very well be known by Maunan Church, which ≈øtandeth on a Hill on the north ≈øide, as you may ≈øee in the Draught of Falmouth, &c. Right off from the Point of the Lizard lyeth a parcel of ≈øteeped Rocks above water,Staggs Lizard. called the Staggs; they lye off ≈øouth from the ≈øhoar into the Sea, about a ≈øhort mile off; they are ≈øteep too: you ≈øhall have twelve Fathom clo≈øe to them.

div.head: Directions for Sailing into Mounts-Bay.
div.p: MOunts-Bay Mounts-Bay. lyeth north we≈øt from the Lizard ≈øix Leagues, and three Leagues from the Lands end. On the ea≈øt ≈øide of Mounts-Bay is a high pecked I≈øland, called the Mount, on the top of which is an old Ca≈øtle, and on the north we≈øt ≈øide of the Mount is a ≈ømall Peer, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground at low-water, and lyeth from the Main about a quarter of a mile: you go over dry at low-water.

div.head: Eglandkey.
div.p: Eglandkey Eglandkey. are a parcel of ≈øunk Rocks, which lye ≈øouth ea≈øt about two or three miles from the Mount, and about a mile from the we≈øt ≈øhoar; there is not above eight or nine foot on them at low-water.

div.head: Pen≈øance.
div.p:
In the north we≈øt of this Bay is a ≈ømall Pen≈øance.
Peer, called Pen≈øance, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground at low-water.

div.head: Govers-Lake.
div.p: On the we≈øt ≈øide of Mounts-Bay, Govers-Lake. over again≈øt the Mount, is a Bay called Govers-lake, and is a good Place to Anchor in, becau≈øe you bring the ≈øunken Rocks of Carrenba≈øe and Lowleigh ≈øouth ea≈øt from you, which Rocks break off the Sea, on which there is but four and five foot at low-water; they lye about a quarter of a mile from the we≈øt Land, and bear from St. Paul's Church north we≈øt by we≈øt, and we≈øt north we≈øt. To Anchor in Govers-lake To anchor in Govers-Lake. you mu≈øt bring St. Paul's Church ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth, and St. Clement's I≈øland ≈øouth and ≈øouth by ea≈øt, and Pen≈øance north, and you will have four and five Fathom water at low-water on a Spring tyde. Keep St. Paul's Steeple above the Land, (that is) that you keep ≈øight of it, and then you will run without Lowleigh and Carrenba≈øe, that is, you will go to the ea≈øtward of them.

div.head: Mou≈øehole.
div.p: There is a ≈ømall Peer at Mou≈øehole, Mou≈øehole. but now gone to decay.
You may Anchor in Mounts-Bay To anchor in Mounts Bay. as you plea≈øe, from twenty to ≈øeven Fathom water, as you may ≈øee in the Draught, Number 27.
It floweth here at Full and Change half an hour pa≈øt four, that is, ea≈øt north ea≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe eighteen and nineteen foot.

div.head: Rundle-≈øtone.
div.p: From Mounts-Bay to the Lands-end the ≈øhoar is bold; and a mile, or a mile and a half due ≈øouth from the Lands-end, lyeth a Rock called the Rundle-≈øtone, Rundle-≈øtone. and ≈øheweth above water from half Ebb to half Flood, and then under water there is twenty Fathom water between the Lands-end, and this Stone.

div.head: Gulf-Rock.
div.p: Gulf-Rock.The Gulf is a ≈ømall Rock, and always above water, and lyeth from the Lands-end ≈øouth we≈øt three Leagues; this Rock is ≈øteep too on every ≈øide, and is no bigger then an ordinary Long-boat: Keep the outward part of the Long≈øhips on the Brizan I≈øland, and that will carry you ju≈øt on the Gulff. There is forty Fathom water within a quarter of a mile of it.

div.head: Long-≈øhips.
div.p: From the Lands-end to the Long-≈øhips Long ≈øhips. the Cour≈øe is north we≈øt by north two Leagues. The≈øe Rocks are high above water, and lye in length we≈øt two miles from the Land; it is all foul Ground between them and the Land; yet I have been told that ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels that are well acquainted will Sail within them. To the northward of them is a ≈ømall Bay, called White-≈øand-Bay, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels and Coa≈øters anchor.

div.head: Brizan-I≈øland.
div.p: From the Long-≈øhips to the Brizan-I≈øland Brizan-I≈øland. the Cour≈øe is north north ea≈øt, about five or ≈øix miles. This is a high ≈ømall round I≈øland, and lyeth to the we≈øtward of Cape Cornwall a mile from the ≈øhoar. Them that are well acquainted Sail within the I≈øland.

div.head: Seven-≈øtones.
div.p: Seven-≈øtones Seven-≈øtones. are a parcel of Rocks that lye from the Brizan and Cape Cornwall we≈øt half ≈øouth, about ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues, and ≈øhew them≈øelves above water at half Tyde; they lye in length north we≈øt and ≈øouth ea≈øt about two miles, and half a mile broad: they bear from St. Martin's-head at Scilly north ea≈øt three Leagues, and are very dangerous.

The fir≈øt place of the beginning of the Flood in the We≈øt of England, is at the Long ≈øhips, which Place divides the Stream, one ≈øetting to the northward, and the other to the ≈øouthward. At Full and Change the Flood begins ea≈øt north ea≈øt, and ≈øets nine hours to the northward: And from the Long-≈øhips to the Rundle-≈øtone and Gulff, the Tyde ≈øetteth ≈øouth ea≈øt three hours, that is, it is high-water by the ≈øhoar, before the Flood ≈øetteth to the ≈øouthward.

At the Seven-≈øtones, The ≈øtream ≈øetteth 9 hours to the northward and but 3 to the ≈øouthward. and between Scilly and the Lands-end, the fir≈øt of the Flood ≈øetteth north we≈øt, and endeth in the north ea≈øt nine hours; and the Stream beginneth to ≈øet to the ≈øouthward at high-water, which is ea≈øt north ea≈øt a≈øhoar.

It is high-water at the Gulff at Full and Change ea≈øt north ea≈øt, and the Tyde ≈øetteth to the ea≈øtward till half Ebb a≈øhoar. And when it is half Ebb a≈øhoar at Mounts-Bay, then the north ≈øtream begins in the north we≈øt, and ends in the north ea≈øt nine hours, till it is high-water a≈øhoar.

div.head: Directions for Sailing in and out at the ≈øeveral Sounds at the I≈ølands of Scilly.
div.p: THe≈øe I≈ølands lye to the we≈øtward of the Lands-end of Cornwall nine or ten Leagues, and are many I≈ølands and Rocks, you may ≈øee them ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues off the ≈øouth we≈øt: Part of the≈øe I≈ølands are very Rocky, but are bold. On the ≈øouthernmo≈øt big I≈øland there ≈øtandeth a high Light-hou≈øe, erected by the Corporation of Trinity-Hou≈øe, Deptford-Strand, and is a mo≈øt excellent good Light, and may be ≈øeen ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues off. Before this Light-Hou≈øe was erected, there was not a Winter but there were ≈øome Ships ca≈øt away: but ≈øince the erecting of it, there hath not a Ship been lo≈øt, but by Ignorance; ≈øo that Navigation is much obliged to the great care of Trinity-Hou≈øe in erecting this Light.

div.head: St. Mary's Road.
div.p: How to Sail into St. Mary's Sound.The principal Road is St. Mary's Road, and the be≈øt and mo≈øt common Sound to go in to it, is St. Mary's Sound, between St. Mary's I≈øland and the I≈øland Gugh. Being to the ea≈øtward of the I≈øland, you mu≈øt run in at the ≈øouth ≈øide of St. Mary's; you may know St. Mary's I≈øland by the Ca≈øtle and two Wind-wills, which ≈øtand on the ≈øouth we≈øt part of the I≈øland; run boldly in with the Mills, keeping clo≈øe by St. Mary's ≈øide, which is very bold. In the fair way between Penmis Point and the Gugh, lyeth a Ledge of Rocks, called the Spani≈øh Ledge, Spani≈øh-Ledge. on which is but ≈øix foot at low-water, therefore keep clo≈øe to Penmis, and then ≈øteer away for the Hughland, on which ≈øtand the Ca≈øtle and Wind-mills, giving them a fair birth to avoid the Woolpack, Woollpack. which is a ≈øunk Rock clo≈øe by the ≈øouth end of the Hugh. You may boldly Sail within a quarter of a mile of the Hugh, from the Woolpack to the Stevern, and that will carry you clear of Bartholomew-Ledge, Bartholomew-Ledge. which hath but ≈øix foot water at low-water, and lyeth ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt from the Stevern, about half a mile; between the Stevern and the Gugh, when you have the Light-Hou≈øe ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth, then are you abrea≈øt of it. There are two leading Marks to avoid the Spani≈øh Ledge and Bartholomew Ledge; keep the high Land of Samp≈øon on the Stevern, and that will carry you clear of the Spani≈øh Ledge; and being pa≈øt it, then keep Ca≈øtle Bryer, which is a high round Rock, on the low-land of Samp≈øon, and that will carry you clear of Bartholomew Ledge. But if you are not ≈øure of knowing the≈øe Marks, I advi≈øe you to your former Directions of keeping a quarter of a mile from the Hugh, or if you keep ≈øight of the Vanes of the Wind mills, but not the Mills, that is, keep ≈øight of half the Vanes above the Land, and that will carry you between Bartholomew Ledge and the Stevern. If you will fire a Gun, and make a Whaff, you will have a Pilot come off. Being about the Stevern Rock,How to Anchor in St. Mary's Road. ≈øteer in to the Road, and bring the Nut Rock we≈øt north we≈øt, or north we≈øt by we≈øt about half a mile from the Rock, or a quarter of a mile; or bring the Ca≈øtle ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and anchor in five Fathom water at low-water, or ≈øeven or eight at high-water. Here you ride well for all Winds but ≈øouth we≈øt Winds, which Winds bring in a great Sea. It floweth here at Full and Change ea≈øt north ea≈øt.
There is a ≈ømall PeerPeer. at the Hugh Town, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground at low-water, and is a good place to clean, wa≈øh, tallow, or ≈øtop leaks, &c.

div.head: Crow-Sound.
div.p: Crow-Sound Crow-Sound. lyeth at the north end of St. Mary's I≈øland, and is a Bar-Channel, where at low-water there is not above four foot water, therefore to Sail in here you mu≈øt take the Tyde. To Sail into Crow-Sound, you mu≈øt Sail clo≈øe by the north end of St. Mary's, off of which place lyeth a Sandy Point, and maketh the Bar. Being over the Bar, there lyeth a Rock a quarter of a mile from the ≈øhoar, called the Crow, and is above water at half Tyde: between it and the ≈øhoar is no more then ≈øix or ≈øeven foot at low-water. To Sail between this Rock and the ≈øhoar, you mu≈øt keep within half a quarter of a mile of the ≈øhoar, or a Cables length. But I advi≈øe no Man to go into this Place without a Pilot, except well acquainted. If you fire a Gun, and make a Whaff, you will have a Pilot come off.

div.head: Broad-Sound.
div.p:
Broad-Sound Broad-Sound. is a dangerous Sound for tho≈øe that are not acquainted. There are two Channels that lead you into this Sound, the ≈øouth we≈øt Channel, and the north we≈øt
Channel. To Sail in at the ≈øouth we≈øt Channel, which is the be≈øt of the two, you mu≈øt Sail in between the Bi≈øhop and the Crim, which are the two we≈øternmo≈øt Rocks of Scilly, and are a good height above the water, then ≈øteer in north ea≈øt by ea≈øt, keeping the I≈ølands of Great Gannelly and Great Gannick open and ≈øhut of St. Mary's I≈øland, as you may ≈øee in the Draught of the I≈ølands of Scilly, Number 20. and with this Mark you run in among≈øt many Rocks very terrible to behold, and the Marks difficult to be known; therefore I advi≈øe none to Sail in here without a Pilot from the I≈øland.

div.head: Smith's-Sound.
div.p: Smith's-Sound. Smith's-Sound is likewi≈øe a dangerous Sound, and very narrow. This Sound lyeth on the we≈øt ≈øide of the I≈øland Agnis, on which ≈øtandeth the Light-Hou≈øe. The Mark to Sail in is to bring Ca≈øtle-Bryer, which is a high round Rock above water on the Great Smith, as you may ≈øee in the Draught; and this Mark will carry you in between St. Agnis, Melledgan, and a ≈ømall Rock called Menpingo, and being between the I≈øland St. Agnis and the I≈øland Annet, ≈øteer then between Annet and the Great Smith Rock; being about the Rock, ≈øteer in for St. Mary's Road, as before.

div.head: New Grimsbay.
div.p: New Grimsbay. New Grimsbay is a Road, or rather a ≈ømall Cove between the I≈øland of Tre≈øco and the I≈øland Bryer; there is no danger in going in. This Place is narrow, and only fit for ≈ømall Ships. You Anchor before the Ca≈øtle in five, ≈øix, or ≈øeven Fathom water. At low-water it is dry between Tre≈øco and Bryer.

div.head: Old Grimsbay.
div.p: Old Grimsbay. Old Grimsbay is a Place where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels may ride. There are two Channels in and out, and very narrow, and not to be made u≈øe of except you have a Pilot.

It is high-water at all the I≈ølands of Scilly at Full and Change, half an hour pa≈øt four, that is, ea≈øt north ea≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall 21 and 22 foot, and the Neaptydes fifteen and ≈øixteen foot.

The Tyde or South-≈øtream ≈øetteth out of St. Mary's Sound from half Flood to half Ebb. The we≈øt ≈øtream cometh into St. Mary's Sound from half Ebb to half Flood, and runneth out through Broad-Sound.

Note that about Scilly, and for ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues to the we≈øtward of it, and from the I≈ølands to the Lands-end of England, the North-≈øtreamNorth Stream. runneth nine hours to the northward, and beginneth to ≈øet to the northward the la≈øt quarter Ebb, beginning to ≈øet to the north we≈øt, and ≈øo altering till it end in the north ea≈øt, at which time it will be high-water a≈øhoar at Scilly, and then the South Tyde cometh and runneth three hours to the ≈øouthward.

You may ≈øee the I≈ølands of Scilly from the ≈øouth in ≈øixty Fathom water, ≈øhelly, ≈øandy Ground, at which time you will be ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues of; and from the north in ≈øixty Fathom, about ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues of ow≈øey ≈øandy Ground. Twenty one or twenty two Leagues we≈øt by north and we≈øt north we≈øt from Scilly, is a BankA Bank. on which is but fifty, fifty one, and fifty two Fathom water, and between Scilly and this Bank ≈øixty Fathom.

div.head: Directions for Sailing up the Severn into Bri≈øtol.
St. Ives.
div.p: ST. Ives St. Ives. is a Place where Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground at low-water, and is four Leagues to the ea≈øtward of Cape Cornwall, in a ≈øandy Bay.

div.head: Lundy.
div.p: Lundy Lundy. is a high I≈øland which lyeth in the Severn: at the ea≈øt ≈øide of it is good Anchoring in ten and twelve Fathom water for we≈øterly Winds.

div.head: Barn≈øtable.
div.p: Barn≈øtable Barn≈øtable is a Bar-Haven, where good Ships may go in at half Flood. There are many Ships belong to this Place: It is very good riding in the Bay without the Bar. This Place is not yet ≈øurveyed by me, but I intend it God willing, &c.

Going up the Severn, you cannot mi≈øs the I≈øle of Lundy, it lying in the fair way. The Engli≈øh Coa≈øt is bold and ≈øteep, but the
Welch Coa≈øt full of Sands and Shoals; you may ≈øail off either ≈øide of Lundy but ≈øtand no farther than 3 Leagues from Lundy towards the Welch Coa≈øt to avoid the Sands: from Lundy ≈øteer along the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt, till you come up as high as Purlock Purlock. or Minehead, and then ≈øteer away north ea≈øt between the Steep Holmes and the Flat Holmes: the ≈øouth I≈øland next the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt is called the Steep Holme, and is high round Land; the north I≈øland is low Land, and is called the Flat Holme; there is deep water between them; keep neare≈øt the Flat Holme, which is the ≈øteepe≈øt ≈øide, you may ≈øail clo≈øe to it without any danger. Being up with the Flat Holmes, ≈øteer away to the northward till you bring the Flat Holme ≈øouth we≈øt, and keep it ≈øo for three or four miles, till you have a Mill that ≈øtandeth on a Hill comes on the we≈øt end, a Land that ≈øheweth like an I≈øland; or bring the Mill ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth, then you are pa≈øt the Point of the Engli≈øh Ground; then ≈øteer away ea≈øt north ea≈øt on the ≈øide of the Engli≈øh Ground, which are flat, and keep the Lead going. The Tydes ri≈øe here at a Spring ≈øeven and eight Fathom; ≈øo if you bring a Tyde with you, you cannot come to any damage; and ≈øteer amay to Po≈ølet Point, which is ≈øteep too. A little above that is King's Road, where you Anchor; but be ≈øure when you Anchor at high-water, that you con≈øider how much the Tydes fall. Here you take a Pilot to carry you into Hung-Road, and ≈øo up to Bri≈øtol.

div.head: Hung-Road.
div.p: Hung-Road. Hung-Road is a Place where great Ships lye afloat by the ≈øhoar ≈øide, and there Careen, having no Dock. Le≈ø≈øer Ships go up to the City of Bri≈øtol.

Tho≈øe Ships that have occa≈øion to go above King-Road up the Severn, or up to Chep≈øtow, mu≈øt take a Pilot. Note that the Tydes are very ≈øtrong in all the Severn from Milford to King-Road. There are ≈øeveral Places on the Welch and Engli≈øh ≈øides of the Severn, but being Places only for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels. And ≈øuch as are acquainted, I advi≈øe ≈øuch as have occa≈øion to make u≈øe of them, to take a Pilot. In going up and down the Severn, you mu≈øt be very careful to keep the Lead when you ≈øtand over to the Welch Sands.

div.head: Minehead.
div.p: Minehead Minehead. is a Stone Peer, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels lye aground: Here Ships that are not acquainted, may have a Pilot for Bri≈øtol. You may Anchor in the Road before Minehead.
The Draught of the Severn is not ≈øo well fini≈øhed as was intended, by rea≈øon the Ingraver lo≈øt the Original Copy.

If any Ship that may be bound up the Engli≈øh Channel, and ≈øhould happen to come up the Severn, and have not a Wind to get into the Engli≈øh Channel, then I advi≈øe them to go for Milford. See the Directions for Milford.

div.head: Milford-Haven.
div.p: MIlford-Haven is very ea≈øily to be known,There are three Hills up in the Country, which you ≈øee fir≈øt at Sea in clear weather, and bear from the Harbours mouth north ea≈øt by north. having the I≈øland of Scoockam, Scanmore, and Gre≈øholme on the we≈øt, and the I≈øle of Lundy to the ea≈øt. You may know the going in by an old Light-Tower which ≈øtandeth on St. Anns Point: likewi≈øe you will ≈øee two old Stone-Blockhou≈øes or Forts which ≈øtand on each ≈øide on the Cliffs going in; likewi≈øe Sheep-I≈øland, which lyeth ju≈øt at the Entrance on the ea≈øt ≈øide, and another I≈øland within the Entrance, called Rat-I≈øland, and is like the Mew≈øtone at Plymouth, but le≈ø≈øer. To the we≈øtward of which I≈øland lyeth a ≈øunk Rock about a quarter of a mile of, on which there is ≈øixteen and ≈øeventeen foot at low-water on Springtydes. A long mile within this Ratt-I≈øle lyeth a great Rock above water, called the Stack, this Rock is bold. Angle-Road is the be≈øt place to Anchor in, but in truth the whole Haven is very good and ≈øafe. Ships may ride afloat as high as Langham-ferry and Coetcanles, in three, four, and five Fathom water at low-water. Small Ships may ride afloat in Crowpool within Pennet-mouth, and may go up with the Tyde to Pembroke Key, and there lye aground at low-water; ≈ømall Ships go up to Land≈øhipping-Key, where Sir Hugh Owen hath made all Conveniencies for loading of Coals: ≈ømall Ships likewi≈øe go up to Haverford-we≈øt and Cro≈øswell with the Tyde. The Colliers that are bound out commonly lye in Dale-Road. It floweth here at Full and Change, ea≈øt and we≈øt neare≈øt.

div.head: A farther De≈øcription of Milford-Haven.
div.p: Milford-Haven. MIlford-Haven is certainly the be≈øt Harbour in the three Kingdoms, there being no manner of danger in Sailing in or out of the Harbour, ≈øo that you need no Pilots, and may turn in and out with ≈øafety with contrary Winds, taking the Tyde, as well by Night as by Day. When you are entred into the Harbour, you may Anchor where you plea≈øe, according as the Ship is in bigne≈øs: And if a Ship come in without Cable and Anchor, ≈øhe may run a≈øhoar on ≈øoft Ow≈øe, and there lye with ≈øafety.

Here is mo≈øt excellent Conveniencies for hauling great and ≈ømall Ships a≈øhoar, to Grave, Wa≈øh, and Tallow, ≈øtop Leaks, &c. good places to Careen, good places for making of dry Docks, Yards, Store-hou≈øes, Rope-walks, Victualling-Offices, &c. Building and Repairing of Ships, here being good ≈øtore of Timber, good fre≈øh Water, Wood and Coals, Provi≈øions good and plenty.
The Spring-tydes ri≈øe ≈øix and thirty foot, and the Neep above ≈øix and twenty foot, ≈øo that you may lay Ships a≈øhoar at any time.

But that which makes this Harbour more excellent and u≈øeful than any other, is, that in an hours time you are in and out of the Harbour into the Sea, being in a fair way between the Lands-end of England and Ireland, and lyeth in the Mouth of the Severn, and are in eight or ten hours over on the Coa≈øt of Ireland. You may get to the we≈øtward out of this Place much ≈øooner then when you came from Plymouth, Foy, or Falmouth.

Oliver Cromwell ≈øhip'd off his Forces from this place for Ireland, and in time of War kept a Squadron of Ships to Randezvous here; and Henry the Seventh landed here. This Haven lyeth north north ea≈øt nine and twenty Leagues from Cape Cornwall. There lyeth about three Miles from the Havens Mouth a ≈ømall Rock, called the Crow, and ≈øheweth at half-tyde; it lyeth about half a Mile from Lonny-Point.
The Sea-≈øhoar about Milford is about the height of the Land of Plymouth.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the I≈ølands and Rocks which lye to the We≈øtward of Milford-Haven.
Schookham.
div.p: SCookham Scookham. lyeth we≈øt north we≈øt from St. Ann's Point going into Milford a League and a half. Scanmore lyeth north north we≈øt from Scookham about a League, and we≈øt from St. Brid's-head, and is bigger then Scookham.

div.head: Gre≈øholm.
div.p: Gre≈øholm Gre≈øholm. is a high ≈ømall I≈øland or great Rock, and is green, and lyeth to the we≈øtward of Scookham and Scaumore two ≈øhort Leagues. There is a good Channel between Gre≈øholm and Scookham and Scaumore, and are all very bold and ≈øteep too.

div.head: Barrel.
div.p: Barrel Barrel. is a ≈ømall Rock, and ≈øhews at half-tyde, and beareth from Gre≈øholm we≈øt and we≈øt by north about a ≈øhort League, and are ≈øteep too.

div.head: The Hats.
div.p: The Hats Hats. ≈øhew at low-water, and lyes two Leagues to the we≈øtward of Gre≈øholm, and are ≈øteep too.

div.head: The Small.
div.p: The Small Small. is a ≈ømall Rock always above the water, about the bigne≈øs of a Longboat, and lyeth to the we≈øtward of Gre≈øholm two Leagues and a half, or three Leagues: The we≈øt north we≈øt and north we≈øt end is foul and rocky a mile off, and is ≈øteepy too. The Tydes run very ≈øtrong among≈øt the≈øe I≈ølands and Rocks.

div.head: The Ma≈øcus.
div.p: The Ma≈øcus Ma≈øcus. is ≈øaid to be a ≈øunk Rock, and lyeth from St. David's-Head we≈øt north we≈øt three Leagues; but I never could hear of any Coa≈øter or other that ever found it.

There is a narrow Channel between Ram≈øey I≈øland and St. Davids, and is u≈øed by
none but ≈ømall Coa≈øters, and tho≈øe that know it very well. The Tydes run very ≈øtrong, which makes the water to breach and ripple, as though it were ≈øhoal-water; and ≈øo it doth between Gre≈øholm, Scookham, and Scaumore.

div.head: Holyhead.
div.p: It floweth at Full and Change at Holyhead Holyhead. at ten of the Clock; the Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall twenty foot, and the Neep-tydes thirteen and fourteen foot. Between Holyhead and Dublin the Flood and Ebb run north north ea≈øt, and ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt, and floweth ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt.

div.head: Holyhead-Road.
div.p: Road-Harbour. Platters. Cubby, Platters. Holyhead-Road lyeth to the ea≈øtward of Innis-Cubby-I≈øland, to the northward of which I≈øland, about half a little Mile, lyeth ≈øome ≈øunk Rocks which have but three foot water at low-water, called the Platters of Cubby. The Road is clear Sand, the Harbour is dry at low-water, where Ships lye on the Sand, but the Wind out at north makes a Sea in the Harbour. The Pacquet Boats for Ireland u≈øe this place.

div.head: Scarrys.
div.p: Scarry-Platters.Between the Scarrys and Carren-Point lyeth ≈øunk Rocks, and are called the Platters of Scarry, and lye about a ≈øhort half Mile from the Scarrys; therefore keep near Carren-Point which is bold.

div.head: Cole-Rock.
div.p: Cole-Rock.There lyeth a ≈ømall ≈øunk Rock ea≈øt north ea≈øt from the Scarrys about two Miles and a half, and north by ea≈øt from the We≈øt-Mou≈øe a Mile, or a Mile and a half, which hath but ≈øix foot at low-water, called the Cole-Rock. Holyhead is very high Land, as you may ≈øee in the Chart, Number 27.

div.head: I≈øle of Man.
div.p: I≈øle of Man.It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth: The Spring-tydes ri≈øe twenty foot.

div.head: Darby-Haven.
div.p: Darby-Haven. Darby-Haven is a ≈ømall Bay where Ve≈ø≈øels ride affoat or lye aground.

div.head: Douglas-Harbour.
div.p: Douglas-Harbour Duglas-Harbour. runneth into a ≈ømall fre≈øh-water River, where at high-water is ten and twelve foot water, and at low-water lye dry.

div.head: Ram≈øey-Bay.
div.p: Ram≈øey-Bay Ram≈øey-Bay. is a mo≈øt excellent Road, having a Sand without which breaketh off the Sea. In this Bay is a ≈ømall River where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels run in at high-water, and lye dry at low-water. There runneth very ≈øtrong Tydes all round this I≈øland, and in ≈øome places ripple as though there were ≈øhoalwater, e≈øpecially near Point of Air. At this I≈øland the north and ≈øouth Tyde meet; here is great plenty of Fi≈øh of all ≈øorts.

div.head: White-haven.
div.p: A little to the northward of St. Bees-head lyeth White-haven, White-haven. being a good dry Peer, where great Ships take in Sea-coals and carry them to Dublin in Ireland. This place belongeth to Sir John Lowther.

North ea≈øt from Great Orms-head, about a League off, lyeth a Bank north by ea≈øt and ≈øouth by we≈øt about a Mile in length, whereon is not above thirteen foot, being a narrow ridge; on the ea≈øt ≈øide it ≈øhoaleth gradually, but the we≈øt ≈øide is ≈øteep too.

div.head: Directions for Sailing into Beaumorris.
div.p:
THere is a ≈ømall high I≈øland called Prie≈øtholme, on which is a ruined Chappel with a Steeple; half way between this I≈øland and the Main Point called Trwyndu, is a Rock which ≈øhoweth at Half-tyde, called the Hor≈øe, which you mu≈øt leave on the Larboard ≈øide going in, keep in the middle of the Channel between the Hor≈øe and Trwyndu-Point. There lyeth ≈øome Rocks from the north ea≈øt part of Trwyndu-Point, as you may ≈øee marked at A in the Chart, Number 26. The Tydes run in and out very ≈øtrong; therefore the be≈øt going in or out is at high or low-water ≈ølack; the Ebb runneth ≈øtrong upon the Hor≈øe. After you are entred in you may Anchor where you plea≈øe between the Entrance and the Beaumorris. Note that the Depths are ≈øet down in Fathoms
at low-water. You may ≈øail in to the ≈øouthward of Prie≈øtholme between it and Levan-Sands, with a Tyde of Flood, keep neare≈øt to Levan-Sands to avoid the Rocks that lye at the ≈øouth we≈øt end of the I≈øland. The water ri≈øeth and falleth three and twenty and four and twenty foot at a Spring-tyde. It floweth here at Full and Change between the ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt and ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth 10h-30‚Ä≤.

div.head: Directions for Sailing over Carnarvan-Bar.
div.p: Carnarvan-Bar. CArnarvan-Bar hath not above ≈øeven, eight and nine foot at low-water, but then the Tydes ri≈øe four and twenty foot. The Mark of the Bar is Tuttle-hill, and a Tower on the north end of Carnarvan Town, and a little Hou≈øe on the Larboard-≈øide going in, which ≈øtandeth on a low ≈øandy Point; bring the≈øe three in one, or any two of them, and this will carry you into the Ferry, and afterwards Anchor as you plea≈øe, as you may ≈øee in the Draught. There are but few Ve≈ø≈øels make u≈øe of this Bar; only ≈øuch as go to Carnarvan to load Corn, &c. There are ≈øome Ships that have lain wind-bound at Beaumorris bound for Virginia, and not daring to turn out at Prie≈øtholme, have gone through the Swilly, and ≈øo over Carnarvan-Bar; but the Rocks at the Swilly are dangerous, the Pa≈ø≈øage narrow, and the Tydes very ≈øtrong; and be ≈øure to pa≈øs the Swilly at a ≈ølack Tyde. It floweth on Carnarvan-Bar at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt; and the Tydes ri≈øe at a Spring four and twenty foot. Small Ships may ≈øail up to Conaway with a Pilot at high-tyde.

div.head: Directions for Sailing over Che≈øter-Bar.
div.p: Che≈øter-Bar. CHe≈øter-Bar lyeth from Orme≈øhead five Leagues and a half ea≈øt half north; keep Great Orme≈øhead and Little Ormes-head ju≈øt open of each other, as in the Chart, Number 30. and ≈øo run in till you bring the three Hills ≈øouth, then are you on the ≈øhoale≈øt of the Bar, and about two little Miles from the ≈øhoar; then you will pre≈øently have deeper water, and may keep along by the Main in what depth you plea≈øe, keeping Hail≈øand without you, which always ≈øheweth it ≈øelf: this Sand is always above water, except an hour or two at high-water on a Spring-tyde, and then it ≈øheweth by a rippling. You may ≈øail up to Dortpool or Ne≈ø≈øon or Wild-Road or Highlake this way. You will find nine foot water at low-water on a Spring-tyde on Che≈øter-Bar; there are ≈øome Patches on the Bar which alter, but the Tydes ri≈øing ≈øo high as five Fathom at a Spring, and three and a half at a Neep, there is no danger. It floweth here at full and Change between the ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and ≈øouth by ea≈øt.

If you would ≈øail up to Dort-Pool and Ne≈ø≈øon, you mu≈øt have a care of the out Scar-Rocks which ≈øhew at low-water, therefore keep over of the Bugg-≈øide; the thwart Mark of this Out-Scar is Grange-Mill on Kerby-Church; and when you have Kerby-hall open of a Hill then are you pa≈øt them. You may Anchor at Dort-Pool in three Fathom water

div.head: Point of Air.
div.p: Three Miles within this Bar lyeth a low ≈øandy Point, called Point of Air, Point of Air. which you leave on the Starboard-≈øide going in. And three Miles from this place is Moy≈øton Mark within Wild-Road, where Ve≈ø≈øels lade Coals, being half a Mile from High-water-mark; and tho≈øe Ships that cannot take the ground, then ≈øuch Ships may take in their Loading in Wild-Road, and their ride with ≈øafety: Ships may ≈øail from Moy≈øton Mark at a Neep-tyde. This place doth not only ≈øupply the Neighbouring places with Coals, but the Kingdom of Ireland.

div.head: Directions to ≈øail into Highlake and Liverpool.
div.p: BEing on the back of the Hyle≈øand, bring the Mill and Wood one on the other, as in the Chart, Number 30. and run in keeping clo≈øe along≈øt Hyle≈øand, and ≈øo into Highlake, and Anchor.Highlake and Liverpool. Here the great Ships that belong to Liverpool put out part of their Lading till the Ships are light enough to ≈øail over the Flats to Liverpool. K William and the Engli≈øh Army Imbark'd at this place for Ireland. There is a Channel near Formby to go into Liverpool, where is three Fathom at low-water on the Bar; but this place is not Buoy'd nor Bekon'd, and ≈øo not known: the Ships lye aground before the Town of Liverpool; 'tis bad riding afloat before the Town, by rea≈øon of the ≈øtrong Tydes that run here; therefore Ships that ride afloat, ride up at the Sleyne where is le≈øs tyde.

div.head: Pillafoodra.
div.p: Pillafoodra. Pillafoodra is a place where good Ships may go in, but the going in being dangerous to tho≈øe that are not acquainted, I leave tho≈øe that have occa≈øion to go there to take a Pilot, which they may have at Liverpool. This place lyeth out of the way of trade, and ≈øo is but little frequented, and not as yet ≈øurveyed by me.

div.head: Directions for coming into the Channel between England and France, called the Engli≈øh Channel.
div.p: THE Marriner having left the va≈øt Ocean, and brought his Ship into Soundings near the Land, among≈øt Tydes or Streams, his Art now mu≈øt be laid a≈øide, and Pilottage taken in hand, the nearer the Land, the greater the danger, therefore your care ought to be the more.

To be mindful of Tydes and Cour≈øes.Being in Tydes-ways, narrow Channels, Rocks and Sands, I hope the ingenious Mariner will not take it ami≈øs, in recommending this to your care, your Tydes, Cour≈øes, Soundings, and the goodne≈øs of your Compa≈ø≈øes.

To be mindful of your Compa≈ø≈øes, and how to order them.That you have a great care that no Iron be near the Compa≈øs, and that after long Voyages that the Compa≈ø≈øes have been much u≈øed, they will grow dull, and yet the virtue of the Magnet holding good; but that which cau≈øeth the dulne≈øs, and the Compa≈øs being not quick in traver≈øing, is cau≈øed by the Pin's point (on which the Compa≈øs ≈øtands) being worn blunt, therefore ≈øharpen it with a Hone or fine Whet-≈øtone with care and exactne≈øs. And this take for a certain Rule, that the light Card-Compa≈ø≈øes traver≈øe be≈øt in fair weather, and the heavy Card-Compa≈øs be≈øt in foul weather. I mean by the heavy Card-Compa≈øs that which is ≈øtiffned with Mu≈øcovy Gla≈øs, and a Plate of Steel which is touch'd by the Load≈øtone, in≈øtead of Steel-wyre, which is in the light ones. The heavy Card-Compa≈ø≈øes are in bra≈øs Boxes, which are made to open to take the Card out at any time.

Tydes, with their S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gs.The next thing that I recommend to your care, is the ≈øetting of the Tydes, which altereth the cour≈øe to the lo≈øs of many Ships, e≈øpecially when you Sail clo≈øe upon a Wind, then if the Tyde take you on the Weatherbough, you ≈øhall fall much to Leeward of your Expectation; and if the Tyde take you on the Leebough, ir carries you to windward of your Expectation.

Coming out of the Ocean into the Soundings,Depth of Water. which you may know by the water being di≈øcoloured, your be≈øt help is a good Ob≈øervation of the Latitude. The next Con≈øideration is your Depth of Water, with the colour and quality of the Ground.Colour and Quality of the Ground. But as for the colour and quality of the Ground, I think it very uncertain, as I found by Experience lying becalm'd in the Soundings, when I very often heav'd the Lead, and did find one ca≈øt ≈øo different from another in quality, and ≈øtill in the ≈øame depth of water, that I would not have any to tru≈øt to it; only this is generally ob≈øerved, That the Ground to the ≈øouthward on the French Coa≈øt is more gruffer, that is, the Sand is bigger or more gravelly, bigger ≈øhells and more variety, with a ≈øort of ≈øharp ≈ømall things called Needles. We≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt from ∆≤≈øhant eight or ten Leagues, you will have ≈øeventy four and ≈øeventy five Fathom water, and four and five Leagues we≈øt from ∆≤≈øhant ≈øixty eight and ≈øeventy Fathom, we≈øt north we≈øt from ∆≤≈øhant eight or ten Leagues you will have ≈øeventy and ≈øeventy one Fathom, and four, five, or ≈øix Leagues of ≈øixty ≈øix and ≈øixty five Fathom.

North we≈øt from ∆≤≈øhant eight or ten Leagues ≈øeventy Fathom, and five Leagues north we≈øt ≈øixty four and ≈øixty five Fathom; North north we≈øt from ∆≤≈øhant about ≈øeven, eight, or ten Leagues, from ≈øixty five to ≈øixty eight Fathom, and four Leagues north north we≈øt ≈øixty Fathom. North from ∆≤ ≈øhant eight or ten Leagues, ≈øixty four and ≈øixty five; and from three Leagues to five Leagues north you will have ≈øixty Fathom. In the≈øe Depths, Bearings, and Di≈øtances the Ground is white things like Hakes-teeth, and the Ground ruffer then on the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt. But, as I ≈øaid before, that the quality of the Ground being ≈øo uncertain, I would not have any Per≈øons to give any tru≈øt to it.

But on the Coa≈øt of England the Ground is finer in general; for five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven Leagues to the ≈øouthward of Scilly, you will have from fifty to ≈øixty Fathom water fine white Sand, with ≈øome red and black among≈øt it, and ≈øome times ≈øome ≈ømall ≈øhells or pieces of ≈øhells, and at other times white Sand only.

The I≈ølands of Scilly how far ≈øeen.Keep in the Latitude of forty nine degrees thirty minutes, or forty nine degrees thirty five minutes, or forty nine degrees forty minutes, till you have from ≈øixty to fifty five Fathom water, more or le≈øs, as the Tydes may be high; for at Scilly and thereabouts the Tyde ri≈øeth above three Fathom at Full and Change. I have ≈øeen the Lighthou≈øe of Scilly in the Latitude of forty nine degrees thirty five minutes, at which time the Light-hou≈øe boar north by ea≈øt about ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues off, and at the ≈øame time had fifty eight Fathom water, fine Sand with black ≈øpeckles, and pieces of ≈øhells. To the we≈øtward of Scilly the Ground is fine grey and white Sand, mingled with ≈ømall black Sand and pieces of ≈øhells, and ≈øometimes without black Sand and pieces of ≈øhells.

But if you are to the northward of Scilly then your Ground will be white Sand, and ow≈øey Sand: when the I≈ølands of Scilly bear ≈øouth about five or ≈øix Leagues, you will have fifty three to fifty ≈øeven Fathom water. You may ≈øee the Light of Scilly ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues in the Night when it is clear weather.

A ≈øtream ≈øetting nine hours to the northward.Many Ships have fell to the northward (into the Welch Channel or the Severn) contrary to their expectation; the cau≈øe of which is by a Stream ≈øetting nine hours from the north we≈øt to the north ea≈øt, and but three hours to the ≈øouthward: this Stream begins to ≈øet to the north we≈øt when it is half Ebb at Scilly, and endeth in the north ea≈øt when it is high-water. This Stream beginneth ≈øix or ≈øeven Leagues to the we≈øtward of Scilly, and four or five Leagues to to the ≈øouthward of Scilly, and ≈øo between Scilly and the Lizard.

Being to the ≈øouthward of Scilly about the Latitude of forty nine degrees thirty minutes, or forty nine degrees thirty five minutes, or forty nine degrees forty minutes, and having from ≈øixty to fifty five Fathom water, you may keep away ea≈øt in that Latitude, according as you have wind or weather, and in that depth. But when you have ≈øailed about fifteen or twenty Leagues from ≈øixty to fifty five or fifty two Fathom, then if the weather be clear you may ≈øteer northerly for to make the Land. The Lizard Lizard. North by ea≈øt, about nine leagues you will have fifty five, fifty ≈øix, and fifty ≈øeven Fathom water, then will you have pieces of ≈øhells of ≈øeveral colours, thin ≈ømall ≈ølatty ≈øtones, and no ≈øand; meeting with this Ground you may ≈øtand in to the northward into fifty Fathom. Being pa≈øt the Lizard, if you keep without forty Fathom water, you need not fear the Eddy-≈øtone: Eddy-≈øtone you will have forty Fathom in the ≈øtream of the Eddy-≈øtone; if you keep in thirty five Fathom then are you within the Eddy-≈øtone. There is thirty five Fathom between the Ramhead and the Eddy-≈øtone.

For the knowing of the Land when you ≈øee it, I refer you to the ≈øeveral makings of the Land in the ≈øheet, Number 39. And the making of ≈øome Lands are put down in the Draughts of the Harbours; as the making of the Land of Dartmouth is put into the Draught of Dartmouth; Foy and Falmouth the like, &c.

Being ≈øure of your being pa≈øt the Lizard, be ≈øure to keep off from the French ≈øhoar, for fear of the Rocks called the Gaskets, Gaskets. for when you are near them, the Tyde of Flood ≈øets in among≈øt the I≈ølands of Garn≈øey and Jer≈øey: you will have deeper water near the≈øe Rocks, and gruffer Ground then on the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt. You may from the Start to Portland and the Wight, keep between forty and thirty Fathom water, or between thirty five and thirty, according as you go up the Channel.

When you come near the I≈øle of Wight I≈øle of Wight. have a care of the Indraught that ≈øetteth ≈øtrong both into the Needles and St. Hellens, as you may ≈øee in the Directions for ≈øailing into the I≈øle of Wight, which hath drawn many Ships into Fre≈øhwater-Bay, Fre≈øhwater-Bay. and others on the Owers, which lye to the ea≈øtward of the I≈øle of Wight, as you may ≈øee in the De≈øcription of the Owers and Ea≈øt-Burrough-Heads; Owers and Ea≈øt-Burrough-heads. for the la≈øt half-flood, or the la≈øt quarter-flood, and all the Ebb, ≈øetteth into St. Hellens, which hath cau≈øed many Ships to run aground on the Owers, which lye to the ea≈øtward of the I≈øle of Wight. The De≈øcription of which, and how to avoid them, and how to ≈øail from the I≈øle of Wight into the Downs, you may ≈øee in the Directions from the Downs to the I≈øle of Wight; only I would have you to ob≈øerve, that if you ≈øtand over on the French Coa≈øt, that there is a Bank in the Fair-way between Dunginne≈øs and Bullin-Bay, which hath but thirteen Fathom on it, which in the Night may cau≈øe you to think that you are nearer the ≈øhoar than you are.

div.p: The Flood or North ≈øtream cometh in between Ireland and Scotland, and there it is high-water at ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt Moon. At the I≈øle of Man the north and ≈øouth flood meet each other. Between Holyhead and Dublin-Bay it floweth ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt; the Flood ≈øetteth ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and the Ebb north north we≈øt.
This is all that is Surveyed of the Coa≈øts of England as yet. I have added ≈øome Harbours that are mo≈øt u≈øeful in Ireland, being a Third Part of Great Britains Coasting Pilot.

Note that the Letters H and M ≈øignifie Hours and Minutes, and the Letter F. ≈øignifies Feet. As for Example; At Che≈øter-Bar it is High-water at Ten of the Clock, and forty five Minutes, and the Tydes Ri≈øe and Fall Thirty Foot at a Spring Tyde.
