div.p: GREAT BRITAIN's COASTING-PILOT.
The SECOND PART.

Being a New and Exact SURVEY of the Sea-Coa≈øt OF England and Scotland, FROM THE RIVER of THAMES TO THE NORTHWARDS, WITH THE I≈ølands of Orkney and Shetland: DESCRIBING All the Harbours, Rivers, Bays, Roads, Rocks, Sands, Buoys, Beacons, Sea-Marks, Depths of Water, Latitude, Bearings and Di≈øtances from Place to Place, the Setting and Flowing of Tydes, with Directions for the knowing of any Place; and how to Harbour a Ship in the ≈øame with Safety.
By Captain GREENVILE COLLINS Hydrographer in Ordinary to the KING and QUEENS most Excellent Maje≈øties.
LONDON: Printed by Freeman Collins, and are to be Sold by Richard Mount Book≈øeller, at the Po≈øtern on Tower-Hill. 1693.

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN's COASTING-PILOT. The SECOND PART.
The Explanation of the Marks in the SEA-CHARTS or MAPPS.

item.p: THE Depths of water in all the Mapps are all put down at low-water on Spring-tydes, as you may ≈øee in the Mapp going into Harwich, Number E. there you will find that between the Naze and the Stone-Bank, there is one Fathom and half at low-water; but where you find a Line drawn between two figures, as in the Margent, ≈øhew the depth of water at high-water and low-water on Spring-tydes, and if there be the Letter f placed by them, then it ≈øheweth that the depth is feet, otherwi≈øe 'tis fathoms.

As for Example; You will ≈øee at the going over the Bar at Tinmouth or New-Ca≈øtle, there you will find 21 above the Line, and 7 below the Line, as in the Margent; which ≈øhews that on the Bar at a Spring-tyde there is 21 foot at high-water, and ≈øeven at low-water: But if there is not the Letter f by the depth or feet, than the depth is fathom.

list.item: Where you ≈øhall ≈øee a Half-moon placed by any Rock or Sand, it declares that ≈øuch Rock or Sand is to be ≈øeen at Half-tyde.
list.label: ‚Üê
list.item: Where you ≈øhall ≈øee an Arrow in the Margent, it ≈øheweth the Tyde of Flood ≈øetteth the ≈øame way the Arrow pointeth; as you may ≈øee in the Mapp of the I≈øles of Orkney, numbred with the Letter R.
list.label: D
list.item: Where you ≈øhall ≈øee the Letter D plac'd by any Sand or Rock, ≈øuch Rock and Sand is to be ≈øeen at low-water.

div.p: It may be expected that I ≈øhould have given Directions for Sailing from the River of Thames over the Flats into the Downs, and likewi≈øe from the River of Thames down the Swin and King's-Channel, and ≈øo into the Downs. But upon con≈øideration that the≈øe Places are under the Care of Pilots, and for the con≈øtant ≈øupply of them, the Trinity-hou≈øe of Deptford-≈øtrond, have taken care that there be a ≈øufficient number of them, both for great and ≈ømall Ships, &c. I laid the Sands down in the Sand-Chart from the Thames into the Downs, and from the Thames to the Buoy of the Gunfleet, as they were mo≈øt carefully ≈øurvey'd by Trinity-hou≈øe; but all the re≈øt of the Charts or Mapps were actually ≈øurvey'd by my ≈øelf.

div.head: Directions for Sailing over the Spits, the Wallet, and by the Naze into Harwich.
Harwich.
div.p: Harwich. HARWICH being a good and convenient ≈øafe Harbour, and much frequented by tho≈øe that u≈øe the Northern Navigation, and a place where Ships many times are forc'd in by bad weather, I have taken care to give ≈øuch following Directions as will carry any Stranger into that place.

Sailing down the Swin or King's Channel, and that you would Sail into Harwich over the Buoy of the Spits Buoy of the Spits. into the Wallet, you mu≈øt ob≈øerve your Tydes; for at the Spits the Buoy lyeth in five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven foot water at low-water, and the Pa≈ø≈øage often altereth, ≈øometimes more water, and ≈øometimes le≈øs. The Buoy lyeth on the we≈øt end of the Gunfleet-Sand, and the ea≈øt end of the Buxey, bearing from a flat Steeple, called Great Holland-Church, ≈øouth and by ea≈øt: Being over the Spits, you come into the Wallet,
Wallet good riding. where is very good Anchoring in five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, and eight Fathom water; the Sands lying without makes it a mo≈øt excellent Road. There is a good and deep Channel to Sail into the Wallet between the Gunfleet and the West-Rocks, as you may ≈øee in the Mapp of Harwich, Number E. but this Channel is very ≈øeldom u≈øed. Being over the Spits into the Wallet, ≈øteer away for the Naze, Naze. which may be known by the Trees, and a Hou≈øe that ≈øtandeth on it; keep about half a mile, or a mile of from the Naze, to avoid the Stone Bank Stone Bank which hath but five foot water at low-water on it, and lyeth from the Naze Trees ea≈øt by north about a mile and a half from the Naze Point; there is but eight or nine foot water between it and the Naze at low-water.Mark ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Stone Bank Keep Pain's Trees (which lye a little to the ≈øouthward of Harwich) open and ≈øhut with Harwich-Cliff, and this Mark will carry you on the Stone Bank, and the Trees on the Corkland ju≈øt open of the Nazeland will carry you on the Bank al≈øo. There is a good leading Mark to carry you between the Naze and the Stone Bank, Mark „Äà‚óä„Äâ go between ‚Ä¢
Naze
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
Stone Bank. which is Harwich Steeple on Harwich Becon-Cliff, and will al≈øo carry you between the Pye-Sand and the Ridge into the Rowling-ground, Rowling ground where Ships Anchor in three and four Fathom at low-water. The Mark to Anchor in the be≈øt of the Rowling-ground is to bring Harwich Windmill two Sails breadth open of Harwich-Cliff. And to Sail from the Rowling-ground to the Naze keep Pain's Trees open of Harwich-Cliff till you bring the Naze to bear ≈øouth we≈øt, then keep Harwich Steeple on the Becon-Cliff to run within the Stone Bank.

There is a Channel to Sail from the Naze between the Cork-Sand and the Ridge, How ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Sail f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Naze between the C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and the Ridge. keeping the Naze Trees ≈øouth we≈øt, ≈øailing down north ea≈øt between the Cork and the Ridge in five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven Fathom water; and when you have brought Harwich Steeple on the Brewhou≈øe that lyeth to the northward of Landguard-Fort, then are you clear of the Cork-ledge. Cork-ledge. This Channel is much u≈øed by the Light-Colliers going to the northward.

Being in the Rowling-grounds, and that you would Sail into Harwich Harbour, keep clo≈øe by the Andrews, Andrews. which is a Sand that lyeth off from Languard-Fort, and is ≈øteep too on the we≈øt ≈øide; the Tyde of Ebb runneth ≈øtrong over the Andrews the fir≈øt half Ebb, of which you mu≈øt have a care; this Sand is dry at low-water. Keep clo≈øe by the Beach of Languard-Fort to avoid the Altar, Altar. which is a ≈ømall ≈øtoney Shelf that lyeth right we≈øt from Languard-Fort about a Cable and a halfs length from the Beach at the Fort, on which is but five and ≈øix foot at low-water: you may Sail to the we≈øtward of it, between it and Harwich-Cliff,
according as the Tyde is up, and what drought of water your Ship draweth. But if you ≈øhould chance to go into Harwich at low-water, and your Ship draw above fifteen foot, you mu≈øt ≈øtay for the Flood to have water over the Glutton, Glutton. which is a narrow Ridge, and ≈øtretcheth off from the Beach thwart the Channel a little within the Brewhou≈øe that is to the northward of Languard-Fort. Being pa≈øt the Glutton, you mu≈øt keep clo≈øe to the Beach to avoid the Gri≈øtle
‚Ä¢ ri≈øtle. that lyeth in the middle between Harwich and the Beach of Languard-Fort, on which is but three foot at low-water. There is a ≈ømall Channel between the Gri≈øtle and the Guard
‚Ä¢ uard. of nine foot at low-water, but when you have opened Dover-Court Church of Harwich Town, then are you clear of the Gri≈øtle and Guard, and may Anchor before the Town of Harwich
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rwich ‚Ä¢ arbour. in five Fathom water, or run up into Ip≈øwich-water and Anchor. This is a very ≈øafe Harbour; and if a Ship ≈øhould chance to blow a≈øhoar, ≈øhe cannot take any harm, the ≈øhoars being ≈øoft Ow≈øe.

There is a Yard at Harwich where many of the great Ships of the Navy have been built, where is a convenient place to haul ≈øuch Ships (as can take the ground) a≈øhoar to Wa≈øh, Tallow, ≈øtop Leaks, &c. This place is much approved of by the Commanders of Virginia Ships, being very convenient for unloading their Goods, having good Store-hou≈øes for that purpo≈øe by the water ≈øide, and is the be≈øt Inlet and Outlet between England and Holland, as is experienced by the Pacquet-Boats, having made this place their ≈øtation. It floweth here at Full and Change in the Harbour ≈øouth; the Spring-tydes ri≈øe fifteen and ≈øixteen foot, and the Neap-tydes ten and eleven foot.

div.head: Directions for to Sail into Harwich through the Sledway.
div.p:
BEing at the Buoy of the Spits, and that you will not Sail over the Spits, then keep down by the Gunfleet-Sand
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nfleet. in ≈øeven and eight Fathom water, till you come within two Miles of the Buoy of the Gunfleet, and then come no nearer then nine Fathom; for there lyeth off a Spit ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt from the Sand, about a Cables length. To the ea≈øtward of this Spit is a ≈ømall Swatch through the Sand, into which and Goldmore's-Gatt, Goldmore's Gatt. the Tyde of Flood ≈øetteth ≈øtrong into the Wallet, of which you mu≈øt have a care when you come near it, e≈øpecially in little Wind or Calms you may be hauld on the Gunfleet-Sand. This Sand lyeth north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt, and drieth in ≈øeveral places. The Buoy of the Gunfleet Buoy of the Gunfleet. beareth from the Naze ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt ea≈øterly. You may ≈øtand into ≈øeven and eight Fathom along the ≈øide of the West-Rocks We≈øt-Rocks. into the Sledway, keeping Bal≈øey Church north by we≈øt and north north we≈øt till you bring Harwich Steeple on the Brewhou≈øe (that lyeth to the northward of Languard-Fort) which will carry you clear of the Cork-ledge, on which is two Fathom and a half at low-water, and then ≈øtand to the we≈øtward, and keep Orford Church and Ca≈øtle open of Bal≈øey-Cliff a Sails breadth, till you have the Lights together, keeping them ≈øo till you are pa≈øt the Andrews, and then follow the former Directions for ≈øailing into Harwich. You may ≈øtand in upon the Platters Platters. into five Fathom, on which Sand is but two and three foot at low-water; the Ridge hath ≈øeven foot at low-water. A great part of the Cork-Sand Cork. dryeth at low-water; and lyeth in length northea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt about two miles and a half long, and a mile broad.

div.head: We≈øt-Rocks.
div.p: The West-Rocks We≈øt-Rocks. lye in length north ea≈øt, and ≈øouth we≈øt about three miles, and two miles broad, and dryeth in ≈øeveral places, full of Banks and Swatches, the Ground rocky and ≈øtony in many places. There is a ≈ømall narrow Channel between the West-Rocks and the Cork.

div.head: Directions to Sail from Harwich out the Sledway.
div.p:
SAiling out of Harwich, keep clo≈øe to the Beach of Languard-Fort, ob≈øerving the Directions going out as you did going in, and when you come near the Andrews, if the Tyde of Ebb be made, it runneth ≈øtrong over them the fir≈øt half Ebb, of which you mu≈øt have a care; bring the Lights in one, and Sail out ≈øo between the Andrews, the Ridge, and the Platters, till you bring Orford Church and Ca≈øtle open of Bal≈øey-Cliff a Sails breadth; Sail ≈øo till you
bring Harwich Steeple on the Brewhou≈øe, and then ≈øtand out the Sledway, keeping Bal≈øey Church north north we≈øt out. But if you turn out,How to turn out at the Sledway. then turn Bal≈øey Church on the two Trees to the northward of the Wood; and for the other ≈øide the Church two Sails breadth open of the Cliff. But if you know not the Marks, you may ≈øtand over to the West-Rocks till you bring Bal≈øey Church north by we≈øt, and over to Bal≈øey-Sand and the Shipwa≈øh, till you bring Bal≈øey Church north we≈øt by north and north we≈øt.

div.head: Bal≈øey-Sand.
div.p: The Marks for the ≈øouth end of Bal≈øey-Sand. Bal≈øey-≈øand. is to bring Bal≈øey Church north we≈øt half we≈øt, and lyeth from the ≈øhoar a long League; this end is ≈øteep too, being eight and nine Fathom clo≈øe by it. The Mark for the north end is to bring Orford Ca≈øtle between the north by we≈øt and the north north we≈øt, and the Light-hou≈øe north half ea≈øt. This end lyeth about five miles from the ≈øhoar. Some part of this Sand dryeth at low-water.

div.head: Shipwa≈øh-Sand.
div.p: The Shipwa≈øh Shipwa≈øh-≈øand. lyeth without Bal≈øey-Sand and the Whiting, and drieth in many places at low-water: It lyeth in length north by ea≈øt and ≈øouth by we≈øt about nine miles, and is very narrow, not above a quarter of a mile over in breadth, except the ≈øouth end, and there it is broader. The Mark for the ≈øouth end is to bring Bal≈øey Church north we≈øt half we≈øt about eight or nine miles off. The Mark for the north end is Bal≈øey Church north we≈øt, and Orford Light-hou≈øe north north we≈øt half we≈øt.

div.head: Whiting-Sand.
div.p: Whiting-≈øand.The Whiting lyeth north ea≈øt by north in length about five miles. At the ≈øouth end Bal≈øey Church beareth we≈øt by ≈øouth and we≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt: and at the north end Orford Ca≈øtle north we≈øt by north in five Fathom water. There is good Soundings on both ≈øides of it.

div.head: Woodbridge-Haven.
div.p: Woodbridge-Haven.Lyeth ju≈øt at the we≈øt end of Bal≈øey-Cliff, and is a Bar-Haven, where is but three and four foot water at low-water; the Bar often ≈øhifts there, I advi≈øe ≈øuch as are not acquainted to take a Pilot. After you are in 'tis a very good Harbour, and goeth up to Woodbridge. The water ri≈øeth and falleth on the Bar at a Spring-tyde fifteen foot, and at Full and Change it floweth ≈øouth and ≈øouth by ea≈øt.

div.head: Cutler.
div.p: Cutler. Cutler is a ≈ømall Sand that lyeth right off from Bal≈øey-Cliff about a ≈øhort mile, and hath but ≈øix foot water on it at low-water, and two Fathom between it and the Cliff. The Mark to go clear of of it, is to keep Harwich Steeple ju≈øt open of Fel≈øto-Cliff.

div.head: Ho≈øeley-Bay.
div.p: Ho≈øeley-Bay Ho≈øeley-Bay. is a very good place to Anchor, you having the Sands without, and is very good clean ground.

div.head: Directions for ≈øailing from the Sledway into Ho≈øeley-Bay, and out at Winterton-Ne≈øs.
div.p: BEing in the Sledway you Sail into Ho≈øeley-Bay between Bal≈øey-Cliff and Bla≈øey-Sand; I have given you the bearing of Bal≈øey-Sand already; you may Sail from Ho≈øeley-Bay down to the Ne≈øs all along≈øt the Beach, having good Sounding you may turn down with ≈øafety. Orford-Ne≈øs is a low Beach on which ≈øtands two Light-hou≈øes, but the Ca≈øtle and Church are high, and may be ≈øeen ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues off clear weather. There were formerly two ≈ømall Sands between the Ne≈øs and the Whiting, but they are now worn quite away; the Lights together carry you out between the Shipwa≈øh and Albrough-Knaps.

div.head: Albrough-Knaps
div.p:
Albrough-Knaps Albro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Knaps is a ≈ømall Sand that lyeth due ea≈øt from Albrough Church about five or ≈øix miles off, on which there is but two Fathom at low-water. The Mark to carry you clear be≈øides the Lights in one, is Orford Church and Ca≈øtle together; between the Land and the Shoar you will have twelve, eleven, ten, nine, eight, ≈øeven, ≈øix, and five Fathom good ≈øounding ≈øhoaling gradually. But without this Sand you will have ≈øixteen and twelve Fathom water.

div.head: Directions to Sail from the Buoy of the Spits about the Long≈øand-Head and Kenti≈øh-knock.
div.p: BEing at the Spits, keep the Shoalings of the Gunfleet in ≈øeven and eight Fathom, and if the Winds are contrary, and that you mu≈øt turn down, keep the Shoalings of the Gunfleet al≈øo, till they bring the Naze Trees north north we≈øt, then ≈øteer away north ea≈øt by ea≈øt and ea≈øt north ea≈øt, till the Naze Trees bear we≈øt by north, and then ≈øteer more ea≈øterly till you get into ≈øeventeen or eighteen Fathom water to go clear of the Long≈øand-head and Kenti≈øh-knock, but no Shoaler; then ≈øteer away ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt if you have the Tyde of Ebb; and if you have the Tyde of Flood, then ≈øteer away ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt and ≈øouth by ea≈øt and ≈øouth, according as you have Tydes ≈øtrong or weak, and that will carry you into the North-foreland.

When you are near the Kenti≈øh-knock you may ≈øee the North-foreland, and it beareth from St. Peter's Church on the North-foreland north north ea≈øt ea≈øterly. But from the Long≈øand-head it mu≈øt be very clear to ≈øee the Land. This Sand-head lyeth from the Naze ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt and ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt about five Leagues. At the Knock it floweth north and ≈øouth.

But when you are in ≈øeventeen or eighteen Fathom of water, and that you would Sail without the Goodwin, ≈øteer away more ea≈øterly till you get ≈øix and twenty, ≈øeven and twenty, eight and twenty or thirty Fathom water, and keep that depth till you bring the Lights together which ≈øtand on the South-foreland to go clear of the South≈øand-head; or bring the Land off Dover open of the South-foreland, &c.

div.head: Directions to Sail from the Spits down without the We≈øt-Rocks and Shipwa≈øh.
div.p: FRom the Spits keep in ≈øeven and eight Fathom water down the Gunfleet and West-Rocks; but in turning down be ≈øure to keep the Shoalings of the Gunfleet and West-Rocks, and ≈øtand no farther over to the Sunk then twelve Fathom; the Shipwa≈øh is ≈øteep too, you will have ten Fathom clo≈øe to it. It lyeth in length north by ea≈øt and ≈øouth by we≈øt; keep it fifteen and ≈øixteen Fathom water, and that depth will carry you two miles without it.

div.head: Gallaper-Sand.
div.p: Lyeth in length ≈øouth by we≈øt and north by ea≈øt about nine miles very narrow,Gallaper-≈øand. not being a quarter of a mile broad; and at low-water there is but two Fathom on it: This Sand is ≈øteep too. The Tydes run ≈øtrong over it north ea≈øt by ea≈øt, and ≈øouth we≈øt by we≈øt. A north and ≈øouth Moon maketh high-water. The ≈øouth end beareth from the North-foreland north ea≈øt half north eight or nine Leagues: and the north end beareth from Orford Ca≈øtle ≈øouth ea≈øt and ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt about eight or nine Leagues. The Depths from this Sand to the Shipwa≈øh are from twenty to fifteen Fathom; and on the ≈øouth ea≈øt ≈øide of the Sand from eighteen to ≈øix and twenty Fathom.

div.head: Gabard-Sand.
div.p: Lyeth in length north by ea≈øt and ≈øouth by we≈øt about three miles and a Cables length broad.Gabard-≈øand. The north end beareth from Orford Ca≈øtle ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt and ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt about ≈øix Leagues off, and from the Shipwa≈øh ea≈øt twelve miles, and about eleven miles from the Gallaper. Between which two Sands you will have from ≈øixteen to eighteen Fathom, and from the Gaba d to Orford-Ne≈øs from eighteen to twenty Fathom. And we≈øt north we≈øt from the north end there is a ≈ømall Hole of ≈øix and twenty and ≈øeven and twenty Fathom not a Cables length over.

div.head: The Falls.
div.p:
Is a long narrow Sand lying north by ea≈øt and ≈øouth by we≈øt about five Leagues in length:The Falls. The north end bears from the Lights of the North-foreland ea≈øt north ea≈øt about ≈øix Leagues, and the ≈øouth end beareth from the South-foreland ea≈øt north ea≈øt half north about five Leagues; and from the North-foreland ≈øouth ea≈øt half ≈øouth; and from Callis north we≈øterly. The ≈øhoale≈øt water is near the ≈øouth end, which is three Fathom and a half. This Sand is ≈øteep too,
having twenty Fathom clo≈øe to it; at the north end there is five Fathom.

div.head: Directions for Sailing from Orford-Ne≈øs to Yarmouth.
div.p: FRom Orford-Ne≈øs to Albrough Town the ≈øhoar lyeth north about four Miles, being a Stoney-Beach and good Shoalings. You may Anchor before Albrough in five, ≈øix, or ≈øeven Fathom good ground. Half way between Albrough and Dunwich there is a Wood in form of a Saddle, and is a good Mark to know the Land, being the fir≈øt Land di≈øcovered when you fall in with this Land. The ≈øhoar lyeth from Orford-Ne≈øs to La≈øtiff north by ea≈øt.

Dunwich, Walter-Swick and Sole, or Southwould go all in at one ≈ømall Creek, and divides into three Branches. Dunwich on the ≈øouth Branch, Sole on the north, and Walter-Swick in the middle. This is a Bar-Haven, where at high-water ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels go in; there is good Anchoring again≈øt the≈øe places from eight to twelve Fathom. South-would Church hath a high ≈øquare Steeple, and ≈øtandeth near the Sea-≈øide, as you may ≈øee, in the makings of the Land numbred with the Letter V. Sole-Creek lyeth four Leagues from Orford-Ne≈øs north by ea≈øt.

The Bernard and Newcom are one Sand that lyeth from Carthyne≈øs to Pakefield; the ≈øouthermo≈øt part is called the Bernard, beginning at Cathyne≈øs and ending at Sero; and the northermo≈øt part is called the Newcom, and beginneth from Sero to Pakefield. There is not above three and four foot water on the≈øe Sands at low-water, there is a Channel within the≈øe Sands clo≈øe to the ≈øhoar, where ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels that are acquainted go at high-water; the≈øe Sands lye a long Mile from the ≈øhoar. This Sand hath good ≈øhoalings; ≈øtand no nearer it than four or five Fathom.

div.head: Red-Sand.
div.p: Red-Sand.Lyeth in length north north ea≈øt, and ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt, about two miles in length, very narrow, not above a Cables length over; when you are on the ≈øhoale≈øt part of it, then is La≈øtiff Church about two Sails breadth over the ≈øouth end of the Town. It beareth from Sole Church north ea≈øt by ea≈øt, from La≈øtiff ≈øouth ea≈øt, from Guntonwood ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt. The Di≈øtance from the Sand to La≈øtiff is two Leagues. You have ≈øixteen Fathom between the Shoar and the Sand; the ≈øhoale≈øt water is three Fathom that I could find: but Mr. John Gri≈øt of Yarmouth ≈øaith that he hath very lately ≈øounded it, and found but two Fathom water on it. You will have eight and nine Fathom within half a Mile of it on the in≈øide, and ≈øixteen Fathom clo≈øe by it on the out≈øide.

div.head: Directions for to Sail into the Standford at La≈øtiff.
div.p: TO Sail in at the Standford you will ≈øee a Light-hou≈øe which ≈øtandeth on a Hill to the northward of La≈øtiff, and as you run in you will ≈øee the other ≈ømall Light-hou≈øe which ≈øtandeth on the Low-Beach clo≈øe by the Sea≈øide; keep the≈øe two Lights together, then will they bear north north we≈øt northerly, and run in boldly with the Lights till you come into three Fathom water, or a Cable or two Cables length from the ≈øhoar, then keep along≈øt clo≈øe by the Beach to the northward, and when you have brought the highe≈øt Light-hou≈øe we≈øt by ≈øouth, then you are on the ≈øhoale≈øt of the Standford, between the Beach and the Home, where at low-water you will have but two Fathom, and two Fathom and a half. The Tydes do not Ri≈øe and Fall at the Standford above ≈øix and ≈øeven foot. You may Anchor in La≈øtiff Road in three or four Fathom, to ≈øtay for water over the Standford. At the Standford the Channel is narrow between the Beach and the Home; there is ≈øix Fathom clo≈øe to the Home-Sand. The north part of the Home is called Corton-Sand, for the Home and Corton are but one Sand. Being over the Standford ≈øail down between the Sands and the Shoar into Yarmouth Roads; as you may ≈øee in the Map of Yarmouth, numbred with the Letter F.

But if you happen to turn into the Standford, you may ≈øtand in towards the Newcom into four Fathom, and into the Home-head into eight Fathom; and between the Beach of Lastiff and the Home you may ≈øtand to the Beach into three Fathom, and over to the Home into ≈øeven Fathom: being over the Standford, there is a good turning Channel down into Yarmouth Roads.

div.head: Yarmouth Haven, or Yarmouth Peer.
div.p: Ya ‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ uth H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .Lyeth between two wooden Heads where Ships enter at high-water, at which place the Tydes Ri≈øe and Fall at a Spring but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot, and Neap-tydes four and five foot. The maintaining of the Peers of Yarmouth is very chargeable, and towards which Charge the Town of Yarmouth hath had ≈øometimes Relief by Parliament, for this Haven is the only and chief Place for the Herring Fi≈øhing; and ≈øhould this Peer go to decay, it would be the Ruin of the Herring Fi≈øhing: and notwith≈øtanding the badne≈øs of the Haven, yet ≈øuch is the Indu≈øtry of the People of that place, that they have about five hundred Sail of Ships belonging to that place.

div.head: St. Nicholas Gatt.
div.p:
St. Nicho
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Gatt.Is a Channel that lyeth between Corton-Sand and the ≈øouth end of St. Nicholas-Sand, which is called the Knowle; this Pa≈ø≈øage hath altred very much within this five years, there being now a middle Ground which tails off from the Knowle, on which lyeth a Buoy, which you keep on the Starboard≈øide going in, and Corton-Sand on the Larboard-≈øide: The going into this place is now difficult for ≈øuch as are not acquainted; and ≈øince the Sands have altered ≈øo much, I think it fit to give no further Directions for Sailing into this Gatt, but advi≈øe Strangers to take a Pilot. It is high-water in Yarmouth-Haven at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth nine hours and three quarters; and the Tyde runneth into the Haven, and to the ≈øouthward in the Road an hour and a half after it is high-water in the Haven, which is quarter Tyde.

div.head: Directions for Sailing from Yarmouth Road out at Winterton-Ne≈øs,
div.p: BEing in Yarmouth Road keep clo≈øe along≈øt by the ≈øhoar to Ca≈øter-Lights, keeping the Lights together (to avoid the ≈øouth end of the Cockle) till you come within a Cables length of the Beach, or half a Cables length, then keep clo≈øe by the Beach till you come to Winterton, where are two Lights which you keep together to Sail out at Winterton-Ne≈øs. There is a Buoy on a Spit of Sand that lyeth off from the middle, which Channel is very narrow; you leave the Buoy on the Starboard-≈øide going out.

There are two more Lights which ≈øtand on Winterton-Ne≈øs Sand-hills, and are low Lights, and ≈øerve to keep clear of the north end of the Middle. But the Lights of Winterton is a high Light, and ≈øtandeth on high Land, and is ≈øeen four or five Leagues off. Winterton Church hath a high ≈øquare Steeple.

Note that there is as much water at Winterne≈øs at low-water ≈ølack, as there is at highwater ≈ølack. The Tydes Ri≈øe and Fall here but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot; and at Full and Change it is high-water ≈øouth ea≈øt at nine of the Clock. It is very narrow turning in and out at Winterton. The Tyde runneth in at the Ne≈øs three hours after it is high-water a≈øhoar, which is half Tyde.

div.head: Directions to Sail without Yarmouth Sands.
div.p: BEing off of La≈øtiff, and that you would Sail without the Sands, keep about four or five miles off in twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen, and ≈øixteen Fathom on the back of the Sands. The ≈øouthermo≈øt part of Yarmouth Sands is the Home-head again≈øt La≈øtiff, and the northermo≈øt is the middle at Winterton-Ne≈øs; the Home and Corton are one Sand; the next is the Knowle, St. Nicholas, Scroby and the Calves Knowle, all which are one Sand; there are ≈ømall Swatches over them, and are made u≈øe of by the Fi≈øhermen. The next is the Cockle and the Middle; the Cockle lyeth between the Calves Knowle and Ca≈øter. Some places of the≈øe Sands are dry at low-water. Being on the back of the Sands you may keep four or five Miles from the ≈øhoar of Yarmouth from twelve to ≈øixteen fathom water, which will carry you between Yarmouth Sands and the Newark-Sand.

div.head: Newark.
div.p: Is a Sand that lyeth to the ea≈øtward of Yarmouth, and the ≈øouth end dryeth at low-water; the ≈øouth end of it lyeth from Yarmouth Steeple ea≈øt half north three Leagues, and the north end beareth north ea≈øt half ea≈øt from the ≈øame Staple, and ea≈øt half north from Winterton Light about two Leagues and a half. There is a brave Channel between Yarmouth Sands and the Newark, Newark. the narrowe≈øt place being between the north end of the Newark and the Calves Knowle, which is four Miles, and ≈øixteen, ≈øeventeen, and eighteen Fathom between them. This Sand commonly ≈øheweth it ≈øelf by the Sea breaking on it at high-water: This Sand lyeth north we≈øt by north about four or five Miles long.

div.head: The Overfalls of Newark.
div.p: The Overfalls of Newark.Lye north ea≈øt from the north end of Newark, and lye in length north ea≈øt, having at one place, which is the middle, but three Fathom, and ≈øo deepneth towards each end to ≈øeven and eight Fathom; you have nineteen and twenty Fathom water clo≈øe to them; they lye from the Lights of Winterton north north ea≈øt half ea≈øt about four or five Leagues. I am told that there are more Banks and Overfalls to the north ea≈øt of Yarmouth Land too, on which is but two Fathom and a half; but I have no authentick ground for it.

div.head: Ha≈øebrough-Sand, or the Vrrey-Sand.
div.p: Ha≈øebrough, or the ∆≤rrey-Sand.Is a Sand that lyeth eight Miles from Winterton-Ne≈øs, and lyeth north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt about ≈øeven Miles in length, and very narrow, on which is but ≈øix, ≈øeven, and eight foot at low-water. The ≈øouth ea≈øt end beareth from Winterton Church north ea≈øt by north eight miles; and the ≈øouth end beareth from Ha≈øebrough Church north ea≈øt half north, about ≈øix miles off. This Sand is ≈øteep too, having twenty and one and twenty Fathom clo≈øe by it on the in≈øide and out ≈øide, but the ends lye off ≈øhoal, four, five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven Fathom.

div.head: Leman and Ower.
div.p: Are two very dangerous Sands,Leman and Ow ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . the innermo≈øt is the longe≈øt, and is called the Leman, the body of which lyeth from Ha≈øebrough north ea≈øt by ea≈øt about eight or nine Leagues: This Sand lyeth in length north we≈øt by north about ≈øix Miles, and at low-water hath not above ≈øix, ≈øeven, and eight foot water. This Sand is ≈øteep too, having two and twenty Fathom clo≈øe to it.

The Ower lyeth two or three Miles without the Leman, and lyeth in length north we≈øt by we≈øt about three miles, on which is nine foot at low-water, and is ≈øteep too, having two and twenty Fathom on each ≈øide of it, and two and twenty Fathom between the two Sands. At the ends of Ower you will have three, four, five, ≈øix, ≈øeven fathoms a Cables length off, and then fifteen and two and twenty Fathom.How to avoid th ‚Ä¢
Leman and Ower If you keep a fair ≈øight of the Land you will run within it, for I could not ≈øee the Land from the Ma≈øt-head of the Yatch, when I rid at Anchor clo≈øe by the Leman; but being at Anchor three or four Miles within the Leman, I ≈øaw the Church and Land of Ha≈øebrough. The Di≈øtance between this Sand of the Lemon, and Ha≈øebrough Sand is ≈øix Leagues, and the Depth between them is nineteen, twenty, one and twenty, and two and twenty Fathom.

div.head: Welbank.
div.p: The ≈øouth ea≈øt part of it beareth from Winterton-Ne≈øs north ea≈øt about fourteen leagues,We ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . the north we≈øt part of it beareth north and by ea≈øt ≈øeventeen Leagues, and three Leagues from the Leman and Ower. It lyeth in length north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt one and twenty or two and twenty leagues, and in breadth north we≈øt and ≈øouth ea≈øt twelve leagues at the ≈øouth we≈øt end, which is the broade≈øt, the north ea≈øt end growing narrow. There is on this Bank from thirteen to ≈øeventeen Fathom water; and two and twenty, three and twenty, and four and twenty Fathom between the Leman and Ower and this Sand, and from four and twenty to eight and twenty Fathom. Between it and the Dogger Bank, and the Di≈øtance between this Sand and the Dogger Bank is ≈øix leagues.

div.head: White-water Bank.
div.p: „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Bank.Lyeth between the Wellbank and the Broad Fourteens, and lyeth north ea≈øt and ≈øouth we≈øt about ten leagues in length, whereon is ≈øixteen Fathom, and is di≈øtant from the Wellbank five leagues.

div.head: Dogger Bank.
div.p: The ≈øouth we≈øt end of this Bank lyeth north ea≈øt from the Spurne about ten leagues, and is a ≈øharp Point growing broader to the Sand, as you may ≈øee in the Map. It lyeth in length ea≈øt north ea≈øt northerly about ≈øeventy leagues, and in breadth ten or eleven leagues; the we≈øt end is ≈øhoaler than the ea≈øt end; on the we≈øt end you will have ten, eleven, and twelve, and about the middle fourteen, fifteen, and ≈øixteen; and towards the ea≈øt end from eighteen to four and twenty Fathom. Between Flambrough-head and the Dogger Bank Dogger- ‚Ä¢ ank. you will have from twenty to thirty Fathom.

div.head: Directions for Sailing from Winter-Ne≈øs to the Humbers-Mouth or the Spurn.
div.p: BEing without Winter-Ne≈øs in ten or twelve Fathom, keep along≈øt the ≈øhoar north we≈øt within Hasbrough or the ∆≤rrey-Sand: This Sand is ≈øteep too; you will have two and twenty fathom clo≈øe by it: The ≈øhoar is bold and clean, and very good Anchoring all along. Hasbrough Church ≈øtandeth on high Land, and is a high Steeple, and may be ≈øeen ≈øix and ≈øeven Leagues off at Sea. From Hasbrough ≈øteer along≈øt the ≈øhoar till you come up with Foulne≈øs, which is high Land, on which ≈øtandeth a Light-hou≈øe, but no fire kept in it as yet. From Winterton to this place you may ≈øtand into the ≈øhoar into ≈øeven, eight, and nine Fathom water.

div.head: Blakeney and Cly.
div.p: Blakeney and Cly.Are two ≈ømall Towns which lye into a ≈ømall Creek ten Miles from Foulne≈øs. Blakeney is a great Church, and a high ≈øquare Steeple; bring the Church ≈øouth ea≈øt, and run in ≈øo into five or ≈øix Fathom water, till you ≈øee the Buoy's; there is but half a Fathom of water at low-water, but at high-water thirteen and fourteen foot: You ≈øail in between two Buoys, and then keep the re≈øt of the Buoys on the Starboard-≈øide going in, till you come up with the Beacons, and there you may Anchor, where you will have two, and two Fathom and a half at low-water; if you run higher up, you lye a ground at low-water. It is high-water here at Full and Change ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt.

Wells, Burnham, Lyn and Bo≈øton I have not ≈øurvey'd,Wells, Burnham, Lyn, and Bo≈øton not ≈øurvey'd. being hindred by this pre≈øent War; but as ≈øoon as the War ≈øhall be over, I intend to ≈øurvey it all, with the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øuch Seamen of Lyn and Boston as are be≈øt acquainted with the≈øe places.

Being off of Foulne≈øs Ships, ≈øteer away for the Humber on Flambrough-head, in which Cour≈øe you will meet with many Banks and Overfalls, and this place is called the Well. Many of the≈øe Banks wa≈øh away, and grow up again in time. I have not heard of any Collier of late years that hath been lo≈øt on them.

From Foulne≈øs to the Spurn or Flambrough-head, you ≈øhape your Cour≈øe according as you have the Tyde, of which you mu≈øt have a great care. The Flood ≈øet≈øeth ≈øtrong into Lyn and Bo≈øton Deeps; when you are open of them, the Flood ≈øetteth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and the Ebb north we≈øt. I have no certain Account of the≈øe Banks and Shoals: I have di≈øcour≈øed many able Coa≈øters and Colliers, who all differ much in their Bearing and Di≈øtances from the Land. At Cromer I was told, That ≈øome years ago two Colliers Anchored north north ea≈øt from Cromer as much as they could ≈øee the Land, which might be about ≈øeven Leagues off; the one Ship Anchored in twelve Fathom, the other in two and a half at low-water, and is called in the Map Cromer Knowle. Cromer-Knowle‚ñ™

div.head: Blakeney-Knock.
div.p: Is a ≈ømall Bank, lying about ≈øix or ≈øeven Miles north from Blakeney, Blakeney-Knock. on which is but three Fathom and a half at low-water.

div.head: Outward Dow≈øen.
div.p: Is a Sand that lyeth north from Wells about eight Leagues,Outward Dow≈øen. on which is but three Fathom at low-water.

div.head: Directions for Sailing into the River Humber up to Hull.
div.p: TO Sail into the River Humber, Humber. you mu≈øt have a care of the Dreadful-Sand, on which is but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot at low-water. This Sand lyeth about four Miles, or three Miles and a half from the Spurn. There are two Lights erected on the Spurn, a high Light and a low Light; keep the two Lights together, and it carries you to the ≈øouthward of the Dreadful, as you may ≈øee in the Map of Humber, numbred with the Letter H. There lyeth a ≈ømall Bank between the Dreadful and the Spurn in the Fair-way, on which is but three Fathom and a half at low-water; between the Dreadful and Sand-hail you have 12 Fathom water. Sand-hail ≈øhoaleth by degrees; you may ≈øtand over to the Sand into five Fathom water. The Spurn is a low ≈øtony Beach, on which the Lights ≈øtand; but the Land of Kel≈øey is indifferent high, coming from the northward; the Land is bold and clean; you may come fair aboard the ≈øhoar from Kel≈øey to the Spurn, keeping in five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven Fathom water. About a Mile from the ≈øhoar, and that Di≈øtance, will carry you clear of the Stone-Bank, which lyeth off from the Spurn a quarter of a Mile, or more.

div.head: Bull.
div.p: Between the Spurn and the Bull Bull. there is ten and eleven Fathom water, a brave turning Channel; you may ≈øtand over to the Bull into five Fathom, and ≈øo to the Spurn.

div.head: Hawk.
div.p: Being within the Spurn you may Anchor in the Hawk Hawk. in three, four, five, ≈øix Fathom water: Bring the Light-hou≈øe ea≈øt by ≈øouth about two mile off, and Anchor in five or ≈øix Fathom water good Ground.

div.head: Buoy of Chlyne≈øs.
div.p: The Buoy of Clyne≈øs Buoy of Clyne≈øs. lyeth we≈øt from the Light-hou≈øe on the Spurn four Miles, and two Miles from Clyne≈øs; which Buoy you leave on the Larboard-≈øide as you Sail up.

div.head: Buoy of Burcum.
div.p: And from the Buoy of Clyne≈øs to the Buoy of the Burcum, Buy of Burcum the Cour≈øe is we≈øt north we≈øt three Miles; you may keep about half a mile from the Buoys in a Channel of eight Fathom, and Anchor to the we≈øtward of the Buoy of the Burcum in Grimbsbay-Road in five or ≈øix Fathom. The Buoy of the Burcum lyeth on the ea≈øt end of the Burcum-Sand, on which Sand is but three foot at low-water.

div.head: The Middle.
div.p: The Middle Middle. is a long narrow Sand that lyeth between the Buoys of Clynne≈øs, Burcum and the Sunk. In the Fair-way between the two Buoys and the Sunk there is a good Channel of either ≈øide of eight or nine Fathom water. This Middle hath ≈øix and ≈øeven foot on the middle of it at low-water, and deepneth towards the ends to three and four Fathom. You may ≈øteer up the north Channel between the Middle and the Sunk, keeping the ≈øhoalings of the Sunk in four, five, or ≈øix Fathom; when you come near the we≈øt end of the Sunk, keep neare≈øt to the Sunk, for over-again≈øt it lyeth a Flat off from the ≈øhoar of the Mar≈øh, called Staningbrough-Flats; bring Patrington Church on the Hou≈øe on the Sunk, then are you ju≈øt come on it. Being pa≈øt this Flat, then keep the Larboard-≈øhoar, to avoid the Foulhome; when you have Ottringam Church on Saltawood, then are you abrea≈øt the Foulhome; a Mile above which is Whitebooth-Road, which is the be≈øt Road in the Humber. The Mark to Anchor in Whitebooth-Road is to bring Patrington Church on Saltawood, as you may ≈øee in the Map.

div.head: Hull.
div.p:
From Whitebooth-Road, if you will Sail up to Hull, Hull. ≈øteer away for Poul, and keep that ≈øhoar till you bring a white Hou≈øe, which is the Town-Hall, and is kept white for a leading Mark. Keep this white Hou≈øe on the South-Blockhou≈øe by the water ≈øide, and the≈øe two Marks together will carry you clear of Skitterne≈øs-Sand, which lyeth half Channel over from Skitterne≈øs. You Anchor before the Town in five, ≈øix, or ≈øeven Fathom at low-water, where is a very ≈øtrong Tyde, e≈øpecially upon a Spring. The Ships that belong to the Town go into
the River Hull, and there lye in ≈øafety by the ≈øhoar. It is high-water here at Full and Change Ea≈øt and We≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and Fall eighteen foot.

div.head: Flambrough-head.
div.p: „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .From the Spurn to Flambrough-head the Cour≈øe is north and by we≈øt Di≈øtance nine Leagues, a bold and clear ≈øhoar. Flambrough-head is a high Promontory, on which ≈øtandeth a high Light-hou≈øe, but doth not burn as yet.

div.head: Burlington-Bay.
div.p:
On the ≈øouth ≈øide of Flambrough-head lyeth Burlington-Bay,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ling
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ -Bay. where is very good Anchoring, and clean Ground: In which Bay lyeth Smithick-Sand, on the ≈øhoale≈øt place of it is but ten foot, as you may ≈øee in the Map of Burlington-Bay, numbred with the Letter I.

div.head: Smithick-Sand.
div.p: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thick- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d.The north end of this Sand lyeth ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt from Flambrough-head, di≈øtance two Miles; between it and the Head you have ≈øeven, eight, and nine Fathom water; the ≈øouth end beareth from Burlington-Key ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt, di≈øtance three miles. The ≈øhoale≈øt place of the Sand beareth from Burlington-Key ≈øouth ea≈øt by ea≈øt, and ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt. Within this Sand is very good Anchoring in four, five, and ≈øix Fathom water at low-water. There is very good going in and out at the we≈øt end of this Sand between it and the ≈øhoar; you may ≈øtand in to the ≈øhoar to what depth you plea≈øe by the Lead.

div.head: Burlington-Key.
div.p:
Burlington-Key
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ling
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ -Key. or Peer, is a place where Ve≈ø≈øels go in and out at high-water, and and lye dry at low-water. It is high-water here at Full and Change in the Peer ea≈øt north ea≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe thirteen foot.

div.head: Filey-Brigg.
div.p:
To the northward of Flambrough-head lyeth Filey-Brigg,
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ley- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ igg. which Bridge is a natural Ledge of Rocks that ≈øtretch from the ≈øhoar into the Sea, and is di≈øtant from Flambrough-head three Leagues; within which Ledge you may Anchor in five Fathom water at low-water, and is a good Road for northerly winds.

div.head: Scarbrough.
div.p: Lyeth north we≈øt from Flambrough-head five Leagues; the Ca≈øtle ≈øtandeth on a Cliff by the Sea ≈øide; to the ≈øouthward of which Cliff is a fair Sandy-Bay, where is a good Peer, as you may ≈øee in the Map, numbred with the Letter I; in which Ships lye dry at low-water. It is high-water here at Full and Change ea≈øt north ea≈øt. There is good Anchoring in the Road called Scarbrough-wick, in four, five, ≈øix or ≈øeven Fathom water. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe thirteen foot. From Flambrough-head to Scarbrough Scarborough. the Land is high, and ≈øo Whitby and the River Tea≈øe.

div.head: Robinhood-Bay.
div.p: Between Scarbrough and Whitby is Robinhood-Bay, Robinhood Bay. where you may Anchor in ≈øix, ≈øeven, or eight Fathom water, and is a good Road for we≈øterly winds, but not to the ea≈øtward of the ≈øouth.

div.head: Whitby.
div.p: To the northward of Robinhood-Bay lyeth Whitby, Whitby. where Ships enter at high-water into a River, where you lye dry at low-water; on the ea≈øt ≈øide is a Beacon; you may lye up as high as the Bridge. There is a Rock lyeth off, the Mark to Sail clear of it is Whitby Church-≈øteeple open to the northward of the ≈øouth Point of the Harbour.

div.head: Huntly-foot and Redcliff.
div.p:
To the we≈øt north we≈øt of Whitby it is high land,Huntley-foot and Redcliff. and very remarkable to know the Land by. Fir≈øt there is Huntly-foot, which is a high Hill or Cliff by the Sea ≈øide, and is about three Leagues from Whitby. And to the we≈øtward of that lyeth Redcliff, Redcliff. which is ≈øo called by the Colour of the Earth, which is very red. Between which Cliff and Hartley-Pool lyeth the River Tea≈øe, Tea≈øe. which River is not as yet ≈øurvey'd by me, but as ≈øoon as the Wars ≈øhall be over, I intend to ≈øurvey it. Hartley-Pool Hartley-Pool. lyeth ≈øeven Leagues from Whitby, where is a ≈øtone Peer, in which Ve≈ø≈øels lye very ≈øafe, but dry at low-water. As you go into the Peer there is a Beacon, which you leave on the Starboard-≈øide going in, as you may ≈øee in the Map numbred with the Letter I. There is
good Anchoring in the Road to the ≈øouthward of the Town in four, five, or ≈øix Fathom water. Hartley-Pool is a Penin≈øula, on the we≈øt ≈øide of which is the Peer. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe 13 foot.

div.head: Dogger and Boat.
div.p: Dogger and Boat.Are two Rocks that lye two Leagues to the northward of Hartley-Pool, about a Mile from the ≈øhoar; the Dogger is the bigge≈øt, and ≈øheweth above water like the bottom of a Ve≈ø≈øel, and always above water. The other is le≈øs, and lyeth under water, on which is ≈øeven foot at low-water.

div.head: Sunderland.
div.p: Sunderland.Lyeth four Leagues to the northward of Hartley-Pool, and ≈øeven Miles to the ≈øouthward of Tinmouth-Bar. It is a Tyde-haven, where at high-water, on a Spring-tyde, is twelve foot water, and two foot at low-water; but within in Lady-hole, there is one and twenty foot at high-water on a Springtyde, and nine at low-water. A little within the Bar, ju≈øt without the mouth of the River, are two Beacons, called the Stell-Beacons, as you enter into Lady-hole, and there you lye by the Key ≈øide at Sunderland. Great Colliers that are laden with Coles, and have not water enough over the Stell, take in the remainder of their Coles in the Road, brought out in Keels. It floweth here at Full and Change north ea≈øt. Note that you have a foot le≈øs water over the Stell then over the Bar.

div.head: Tinmouth-bar.
div.p: Tinmouth Bar. Tinmouth is the mouth of the River Tine, called Tinmouth-Bar, and ten Miles from the ≈øaid Bar up the River is the Town of New-Ca≈øtle.

The Entrance of this River may be ea≈øily known by a Ca≈øtle and Light-hou≈øe which ≈øtand on a high Cliff by the Sea ≈øide, ju≈øt on the nroth ≈øide of the going into the River. The Entrance is a Bar, on which is but ≈øeven foot at low-water on a Springtyde, and one and twenty foot at high-water. There are two Light-hou≈øes within the Bar on the north ≈øhoar (be≈øides the high Light-hou≈øe in Tinmouth-Ca≈øtle) and are a leading Mark over the Bar; the ≈øhoar at the north ≈øide going in is rocky and ≈øtony, and the ≈øouth ≈øhoar a Sand, called the Harden'd: being over the Bar, open the Lights to the ≈øouthward, and keep clo≈øe by the Fort on the north ≈øhoar, where ≈øtands the low Light; being pa≈øt that low Light, then Auchor between the two Towns of North and South-Shields. There are ≈øeveral places up this River where are Keys that Ships load at; and ≈øome run up as high as New-Ca≈øtle, and there lye by the Town Keys. The Map of the River Tyne is numbred with the Letter L. Note that the depths of water in the River are feet, and a Line above the figures ≈øhews that is the depth at low-water. But where you ≈øee a Line drawn between the figures, it ≈øhews both high and low-water, as you may ≈øee at Tinmouth-Bar; there is ≈øeven foot at low-water, and one and twenty foot at high-water; ≈øo that the Tydes ri≈øe and fall at a Spring-tyde fourteen foot. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt and north ea≈øt.

div.head: Coller-Coats.
div.p: Is a Peer that lyeth a Mile and more from Tinmouth-Ca≈øtle to the northward,Coller-Coats. and is a Peer where Ve≈ø≈øels enter at high-water to load Coals, and lye dry at low-water. The going in to this place is between ≈øeveral Rocks, the way in is beacon'd.

div.head: Seaton-Sluce.
div.p: Lyeth five Miles to the northward of Tinmouth-Castle, Seaton Sluce. and is a Tyde-Haven, where ≈ømall Ships enter to load Coals. There is in the Peer at high-water on a Spring-tyde, ten foot, and at Neap-tydes when the Ships have not water enough out, they go into the Road and there take in the re≈øt of their loading, which is brought out to them in Keels. There is good Anchoring in the Road in four, five, ≈øix, and ≈øeven Fathom. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth: The water ri≈øeth at a Spring-tyde ten foot in the Peer, and ≈øeven foot at a Neap.

div.head: Blythe.
div.p:
Blythe Bly ‚Ä¢ he. lyeth three miles to the northward of Seaton-Sluce: There are two Beacons on the Sand-hills to the ≈øouthward of the Entrance into the River, which leads you in between two Beacons; and being between the two fir≈øt Beacons, or outward Beacons, then ≈øteer away clo≈øe to the ≈øecond Beacon, and leave it on the Larboard-≈øide, and then run up and Anchor before Blythe-Key, where is ≈øixteen Fathom water at high-water on a Spring-tyde, and ≈øix foot at low-water: but between
the Beacons going in there is but two Fathom at low-water, and ≈øixteen at high-water.
The Rocks which hath a Beacon on it, which you have on the Starboard-≈øide going in, them Rocks ≈øhow at low-water.

There are Rocks that lye to the ea≈øtward of Blythe a Mile off from Blythe, which are above water the la≈øt quarter Ebb, and lye north and by ea≈øt three Miles from Seaton-Sluce Peer, of which Rocks you mu≈øt have a care at high-water, when you Sail along≈øt ≈øhoar. It floweth at Blythe at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt and by ≈øouth: The Spring-tydes ri≈øe ≈øixteen foot, and the Neap ≈øeven foot.

div.head: Cocket-I≈øland.
div.p: Lyeth ≈øix Leagues from Tinmouth-Ca≈øtle, Cocket-I≈øland. and above a Mile off ≈øhoar, and is a good Road for ≈øoutherly winds. From the ≈øouth end of the I≈øland to the ≈øhoar, it is all Rocks and broken Ground, where at low-water at one place there is eight and nine foot, and dangerous; but the north ≈øide is bold, only from the north we≈øt part of the I≈øland lye off ≈øome Rocks about half a Mile; ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels may bring the I≈øland ≈øouth, and Anchor in three and four Fathom, but greater Ships mu≈øt bring the I≈øland ≈øouth ea≈øt, and Anchor in five Fathom at low-water. The Road is clean Sand.
