div.head: Fernie-I≈øle and Staples.
div.p: Fernie-I≈øle and Staples.From Cocket-I≈øland to Ferne-I≈øland and the Staples, the Cour≈øe is ≈øouth, Di≈øtance ≈øix Leagues, and five Mile from Holy-I≈øland. The outward part of the Staples lyeth five Miles from the Main. Between the I≈øle of Ferne and the Main is a good Channel, a Mile and a half broad, where is ≈øeven, eight, nine, and ten Fathom water. Between Ferne-I≈øland and Bambrough-Ca≈øtle is good Anchoring, which place is called Scate-Road, Scate-Road. and is good for ea≈øt and north ea≈øt winds. There is a Light-hou≈øe on the Ferne, but doth not burn. The Staples are a parcel of ≈ømall I≈ølands or great Rocks, and lye north ea≈øt from the Ferne. A Mile without the Staples you will have thirty Fathom, and four and twenty Fathom a Stones ca≈øt off; keep in eight and thirty and forty Fathom, and that Depth will carry you three and four Leagues from the Staples, (and the high Hills up in the Land) called Chevet-hills, Chevet-hills. bear off each other ea≈øt by north, and we≈øt by ≈øouth. The≈øe Hills are ≈øeen eight Leagues off at Sea, and are very remarkable to know the Land. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth. Note that the Flood goeth to the ≈øouthward till it is two hours, and two hours and a half Ebb a≈øhoar.

div.head: Holy-I≈øland.
div.p: Holy-I≈øland.Lyeth five Miles north we≈øt from the Ferne, a fair bold ≈øhoar, five and ≈øix Fathom water. This I≈øland is ea≈øily known by a Ca≈øtle which ≈øtandeth on a high Hill. On the ≈øouth ≈øide of the I≈øland, which ≈øide is little more then half a Mile from the Main, between the I≈øland and the Main, is the Harbour:To Sail between the Staples and the Gold≈øtone. There are four ≈øeveral ways to go in and out the Harbour; Fir≈øt between Ferne-I≈øland and the Main; then between the Staples and the Gold≈øtone; and between the Gold≈øtone and the Plough, and between the Plough and Holy-I≈øland. The broade≈øt Channel is between the Staples and the Gold≈øtone; you may keep within half a Mile of the Staples. The Gold≈øtone Gold≈øtone. ≈øheweth from half Ebb to half Flood, and is a ≈ømall Rock and bold too.

To Sail between the Gold≈øtone and the Plough. The Mark to Sail between the Gold≈øtone and the Plough is to bring the Light-hou≈øe on the Ferne a Sails breadth on the ea≈øt part of the Meg≈øtone, and that carries you between the two Rocks. The Plough ≈øheweth the fir≈øt quarter Ebb, and is a ≈ømall Rock, the north ea≈øt end of it is foul about a quarter of a Cables length. There is another Mark to Sail between the Gold≈øtone and the Plough, which is to keep a hole open in the Wall of the ea≈øt part of Bambrough-Ca≈øtle, which hole, if you ≈øee through, will carry you clear: but this Mark being not ea≈øie to be ≈øeen, I advi≈øe none to u≈øe it but ≈øuch as are well acquainted. The Plough lyeth ea≈øt from the Ca≈øtle on Holy-I≈øland, and lyeth half a mile from Holy-I≈øland. There is five Fathom water at low-water between the Plough and Holy-I≈øland; you may ≈øtand into three and four fathom to the I≈øland.

Being clear of the Gold≈øtone and Plough, How to Sail over the Bar into the Harbo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and that you would go into the Harbour, you mu≈øt ≈øtay for the Tyde, for there is but nine foot water at low-water over the Bar, between the Partner-≈øtill and the Stone-Ridge; bring the Old-Church at Holy-I≈øland north we≈øt, and get the Soundings of the Stone-Ridge, being the bolde≈øt ≈øide; there is one part of the Stone-Ridge always above water, being ≈øhingle Stones, keep clo≈øe to them, being ≈øteep and bold: Having brought the Ca≈øtle north ea≈øt, Anchor in four or five Fathom at low-water. The Partner-≈øtill are a Ledge of Rocks that lye from the Main, and ≈øhew them≈øelves the la≈øt quarter Ebb. There is no failing between Holy-I≈øland and the Main, it being all dry Sand at the la≈øt quarter Ebb. This place is much frequented by the Colliers, when they are put away to the northward of New-Ca≈øtle by bad weather. This Harbour is defended by a Ca≈øtle and Platform of Guns. Here is good convenience to haul ≈øhips a≈øhoar to Wa≈øh, Tallow, Careen, or ≈øtop Leaks. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt and by ≈øouth two hours and a quarter; the Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall fifteen foot: The Flood goeth to the ≈øouthward two hours, and two hours and a half in the Offin after high-water a≈øhoar. The Map of this place is numbred with the Letter M.

div.head: Barwick.
div.p:
Lyeth northwe≈øt and by we≈øt from Holy-I≈øland, Barwick. Di≈øtance three Leagues; there is a Bar at the going into the River,The Map of Barwick was Survey'd by Col. Jacob Richards. where at low-water, at a Spring-tyde, is but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot water; the going in is beacon'd, which Beacons you leave on the Starboard-≈øide going in, keeping clo≈øe to them, as you
may ≈øee in the Map, numbred with the Letter M. Being in, you may Anchor by the Car-Rock, or Still-Rock, where is nine foot at low-water, or run up to the Key by the Bridge. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe eighteen foot, and the Neap thirteen and fourteen foot. There is good Anchoring in the Road: without the Bar is five, ≈øix, or ≈øeven Fathom water.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF THE Ea≈øt-Coa≈øt of Scotland, WITH The I≈øles of Orkney and Shetland.
St. Tab's-head.
div.p: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Tab's- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d.FROM Barwick to St. Tab's-head, the Cour≈øe is north we≈øt and by north, Di≈øtance five Leagues: between the≈øe two is a ≈ømall place, called Haymouth, u≈øed by Fi≈øhermen with ≈ømall Boats.

div.head: I≈øle of Ba≈øs.
div.p: „Äà‚óä„Äâ of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øs.From St. Tab's-head to the I≈øle of Ba≈øs, the Cour≈øe is we≈øt north we≈øt four Leagues. This I≈øland is a high round I≈øland in the Sea, and lyeth on the ≈øouth entrance of Edinborough Frith, a little above a mile from the ≈øhoar: this I≈øland is ≈øteep too all round it; there is fifteen Fathom water between it and the Main. On the ≈øouth ea≈øt ≈øide of it is a ≈ømall Fortification with Guns on it, but naturally ≈øtrong of it ≈øelf, and not to be taken as long as they have Provi≈øions: there is a Spring of fre≈øh water on the top of it. This I≈øland is a good Mark to know the Frith.

div.head: I≈øle of May.
div.p: The I≈øle of May I≈øle of May. beareth from the I≈øle of Ba≈øs north north ea≈øt ea≈øterly ≈øeven miles, and is bigger than the Ba≈øs, but not ≈øo high; on which ≈øtandeth a Light-hou≈øe, that Ships may know the Frith in the Night; this Light may be ≈øeen ≈øix Leagues off. You may Anchor to the ea≈øtward of this I≈øland in Eighteen Fathom water, bringing the Light-hou≈øe we≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt; and if your Anchor hold not you will drive into deep water, of which you mu≈øt have a care to give Cable enough. Dunbar is a ≈ømall Haven, u≈øed by Fi≈øhermen and ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: Keith-I≈øle.
div.p: From the I≈øle of May to Inch-Keith-I≈øland, Keith-I≈øle the Cour≈øe is we≈øt ≈øouth we≈øt, Di≈øtance ≈øeven Leagues, and from Inch-Keith to Leith ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt three miles; bring Leith ≈øouth or ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and Anchor in Leith-Road Leith-Road. in five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, or eight Fathom water.

Leith-Feer, Leith is a Tyde-Haven, where you enter at high-water, leaving the Beacon on the Larboard-≈øide going in, as you may ≈øee in the Map of Leith, numbred with the Letter O. You Sail in between two wooden Peers, and lye dry at low-water by the Keys ≈øide. Here you have thirteen foot at high-water on Spring-tydes, and ten foot at Neap-tydes.

div.head: Queens-Ferry.
div.p: To Sail from Lieth to Queens Ferry. To Sail from Leith-Road up to Queen's-Ferry, Sail along≈øt the ≈øouth ≈øhoar till you come to the ≈ømall I≈øland of Cramend, which you leave on the Larboard-≈øide going up, and the Rock-Muckrie on the Starboard-≈øide, and being pa≈øt them, ≈øteer away we≈øt north we≈øt, till you open Queen's-Ferry-Town, and ≈øo ≈øtand away for it, and Anchor before the Town of Queen's-Ferry in five, ≈øix, or ≈øeven Fathom water. Note that the Tydes run very ≈øtrong here; and tho≈øe that have occa≈øion to Sail further up, I advi≈øe them to a Pilot.

div.head: Brunt-I≈øle.
div.p: Brunt-I≈øle Brunt-I≈øland lyeth ≈øouth by we≈øt from Leith four or five miles, and is a good Tyde-Haven; you Sail in north north we≈øt between two Stone-heads, where you lye dry at low-water. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall here fourteen and fifteen foot, and the Neap-tydes eleven and twelve foot. It is high-water here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth; the ≈øame throughout the Frith.
There are ≈øeveral good Peers in the Frith, but all Tyde-Peers, where Ships lye dry at low-water.

div.head: Port-Seaton.
div.p: Port-Seaton.My Lord Winton hath been at great Charges in building a Stone-Peer at Port-Seaton, where is twelve and thirteen foot water at Spring-tydes, and nine and ten at Neap-tydes. You may Anchor in the Bay before the Peer in ≈øix, ≈øeven, and eight Fathom good Ground.
Note that it is a general Rule for Anchoring in the Frith, that if you Anchor without twelve Fathom water, you will have good and clear Ground.
You may Anchor on the we≈øt ≈øide of the May in fifteen and ≈øixteen Fathom water.

div.head: Carr-Rocks.
div.p: The Carr-Rocks Carr-Rocks. lye off from Fifne≈øs ea≈øt north ea≈øt a mile in the Sea, the outward Rock dryeth the la≈øt quarter Ebb, the others are only ≈øeen at low-water on Spring-tydes. Keep the Light of the May ≈øouth and by we≈øt, and that will carry you clear of the Carr; in the Night come no nearer it then in fifteen and ≈øixteen Fathom water. If you be to the northward of it, you will have fifteen, ≈øixteen, and ≈øeventeen Fathom; and if to the ≈øouthward, you will have two and twenty, three and twenty, and four and twenty Fathom.

div.head: Inch-Cape-Rock.
div.p: Lyeth from Fifne≈øs four leagues north ea≈øt half north;Inch-Cap ‚Ä¢ Rock. from the mouth of the River Tay ea≈øt half ≈øouth four leagues; from the Red-head ≈øouth ea≈øt three leagues and a half, and from the Light of the May north north ea≈øt ≈øix leagues. The I≈øle of Ba≈øs on the I≈øle of May carries you ju≈øt on the edge of the Cape-Rock; but the Ba≈øs on the ea≈øt part of the May carries you clear; you have from eighteen to two and twenty Fathom within a mile of it, except the ≈øouthwe≈øt part of it, and there you will have four and five Fathom a mile off, as Mr. Marr ≈øaith, who is a very ingenious Mariner at Dundee. The Flood runneth over it ≈øouth we≈øt, and the Ebb north ea≈øt. This Rock is about a mile long, and a Cables length broad, and dryeth the la≈øt quarter Ebb, and is very dangerous, e≈øpecially in ≈ømooth water at high-water time.

div.head: St. Andrew's-bay.
div.p: This Bay lyeth to the northward of Fifne≈øs, and between Fifne≈øs and the River Tay, St. Andrew's Bay. in which Bay is very good Anchoring for Landerly-winds. In the bottom of which Bay lyeth the Town and Haven of St. Andrew's, St. Andrew's-Peer. where is a ≈ømall Stone-Peer for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels, where at Spring-tydes at high-water is ten and eleven foot, and ≈øeven and eight at Neap-tydes. Two miles to the northward of this place lyeth an Inlet called Eden, Eden. and at high-water ≈øheweth as though it were a Harbour, but 'tis only a place for Boats.

div.head: River of Tay.
div.p: ‚Ä¢ iver of Tay.Lyeth four leagues to the northward of Fifne≈øs, and lyeth from the Carr-Rocks north north we≈øt. On the north ≈øide of the River is a red Sand-hill, called Bukannais, or Bottonnas, on which ≈øtand two Light-hou≈øes by the Sea ≈øide, being a leading Mark to Sail into the River Tay, between two Sands, the one Sand, which is the north ≈øand, is called the Goa, and lyeth off ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt a mile and a half off from Bukannais ≈øide; the other Sand, which is the ≈øouth Sand, is called Avertie, and lyeth off from the ≈øouth ≈øide of the River, ea≈øt north ea≈øt two miles and a half, and dryeth at low-water. Between the≈øe two Sand-heads in the going into the River Tay, which are a mile a≈øunder, without which Sand-heads is but three Fathom water from Sand-head to Sand-head.

div.head: Directions to Sail into the River Tay.
div.p: BRing the highe≈øt part of Bukannas-Hill north we≈øt, or north we≈øt we≈øterly, or the Lights together, till you bring the high pecked Hill, called Dundeelaw, ju≈øt over Ca≈øtle-Broughty, which is a leading Mark in; you may Sail within a Cables-length of the low Light by the water ≈øide, having ≈øix and ≈øeven Fathom water; then Sail up we≈øt and we≈øt ≈øoutherly, being above Ca≈øtle-Broughty; keep neare≈øt the north ≈øhoar to avoid the Newcom-Sand that lyeth on the ≈øouth ≈øhoar above Ca≈øtle-Broughty, and then Anchor before the Town of Dundee in five or ≈øix Fathom water; bring the Town north ea≈øt, where is a very good and ≈øafe Road for all Winds.

If you ≈øhall Sail into this River when it bloweth hard, and the Sea high, take two or three hours Flood with you, more or le≈øs, according as your Ship is in burden, and be ≈øure to keep a good Head-≈øail: but if you ≈øhould go in with the Tyde of Ebb, and a great Sea, it is very frightful and dangerous for loaden Ships, all the Channel being of a breach.

div.head: Directions for Turning into the River Tay.
div.p: FIr≈øt be well a≈ø≈øured of your Ships ≈øtaying, then take an hours Flood with you, then are you ≈øure of a good Tyde running in with you. In turning in you may open the Light-hou≈øes a little on either ≈øide, and when you are above the Lights, you ≈øtand to the northward into three Fathom water, and to the ≈øouthward to the South-bank, which you may always know by the Ripling or Beach of the water in it; the Lead is not ≈øure, for this Sand is ≈øteep too. You may open the Marks of Dundee-Law and Ca≈øtle-Broughty a little off either ≈øide. The Map of Dundee is numbred with the Letter P. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth we≈øt by ≈øouth. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe ≈øixteen foot, and the Neap twelve foot.

div.head: Red-head.
div.p: From the River Tay to the Red-head Redhead. the Cour≈øe is north ea≈øt by north about three Leagues. A mile to the we≈øtward of Red-head is the Town and Peer of Arbroth, Arbroth. a place for Boats only. To the northward of Redhead is a fair Buoy, called Lounan-Bay, Lounan-Bay. where is good Anchoring in eight or nine Fathom water, Redhead bearing ≈øouth.

div.head: Montro≈øs-River.
Todhead.
div.p: From Montro≈øs to Todhead Todhead. the Cour≈øe is north ea≈øt three Leagues; betwixt both is good Anchoring for Landerly-winds.

div.head: Dounfit.
div.p: From Todhead to Dounfit Dounfit. the Cour≈øe is north north ea≈øt. Ea≈øterly three Leagues on the north ≈øide is Dounfit, it is a good Bay for Anchoring in nine Fathom water, the Point ≈øouth. In the bottom of this Bay is the Town and Peer of Stonehive, where at Spring-tydes at high-water you have twelve and thirteen foot water, and ten and eleven foot at Neap-tydes.

div.head: Girdlenais.
div.p: From Dounfit to Girdlenais Girdlenais the Cour≈øe is north north ea≈øt half ea≈øt four Leagues. A little to the northward of Girdlenais is the Bay of Aberdeen, where is good Anchoring in ≈øeven, eight, or nine Fathom water; you may bring the Point of Girdlenais ≈øouth and ≈øouth by ea≈øt.

div.head: Aberdeen.
div.p: Aberdeen.Lyeth a mile to the we≈øtward of Girdlenais, and is a Tyde-Haven, where Ve≈ø≈øels enter at high-water; you Sail clo≈øe in by the ≈øouth ≈øhoar: the Entrance into the River is very narrow. On the Larboard-≈øide, going in, is a Beacon, you Sail clo≈øe by it; the north ≈øhoar is a low ≈øandy Point, on which is a Block-hou≈øe, which you leave on the Starboard-≈øide. You mu≈øt not venter in here without a Pilot, for the Bar often alters: And you are to ob≈øerve, that no Ship of any Burden, that draws ten, eleven, or twelve foot water, will adventure here, but when the water is very ≈ømooth, and the Winds off ≈øhoar, and Spring-tydes. Here are always Boats ready to help Ships in and out.

div.head: Bokannais.
div.p:
From Girdlenais to Bokannais, Bokanna ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
the Cour≈øe is north north ea≈øt and north ea≈øt by north eight or nine Leagues. In the midway between them, is Newbrough-Creek, a place only for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels.

div.head: Peter-head.
div.p: Peter-head Peter-head. lyeth a little to the northward of Bokannais, and lyeth within Calk-Inch. Here are two little dry Peers, only fit for ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels to enter at high-water.

To the ≈øouthward of Peter-head is a large Bay, where you may Anchor in eight or nine Fathom water, and may Ride with the Wind off ≈øhoar: but have a care that the ≈øoutherly Winds do not catch you there, for then you will have a hard Road.

div.head: Ratter-head.
div.p: From Calk-Inch to Ratter-head Katter-head. the Cour≈øe is north two Leagues. There is a Ledge of Rocks runs off from Ratter-head ea≈øt north ea≈øt a mile into the Sea, therefore keep no nearer the ≈øhoar than twelve or thirteen Fathom; or keep Mormount, (which is a high Hill in the Country, and ≈øheweth like a Saddle) in ≈øight above the Sand-hills of Ratter-head. Mormount may be ≈øeen ten or twelve Leagues at Sea.

div.head: Murrey-Frith.
div.p: Is a deep Bay,M ‚Ä¢ rr ‚Ä¢ Frit ‚Ä¢ . and lyeth in between Bokannais (which is the ea≈øt part of Scotland) and Dungsby-head, which is the north of Scotland. This Bay is known by the name of the North-Frith, as Edinbrough is by the name of the South-Frith. In the we≈øtern-mo≈øt part of this Frith lyeth two mo≈øt excellent Harbours, Cromerty and Inverne≈øs.

div.head: Cromerty.
div.p:
Lyeth to the we≈øtward of Kinnards-head, Crome ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y. which is the north part of Bokannais, twenty Leagues; the going in is almo≈øt a mile over between two high Lands, the ≈øhoar bold and ≈øteep, and no manner of danger in going in or out. The be≈øt Anchoring
is on the ≈øouth ≈øide, ju≈øt within the mouth of the Harbour. The Town or Village of Cromerty lyeth on the ≈øouth ≈øide in the mouth of the Harbour; the north ≈øhoar of the Harbour is ≈øandy, and dryeth at low-water: you may ≈øtand into either ≈øide of the Harbour by your Lead, the ≈øounding being good, and ≈øhoaleth gradually. Five miles above the Harbours mouth it falleth narrow at Inverbrecky-Ferry, where is fifteen Fathom water; and as you ≈øail further up it ≈øhoaleth gradually, there being five Fathom water at low-water five miles above the Ferry of Inverbrecky. The Map of this place is numbred with the Letter Q. This Harbour is able to contain the Navy Royal. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth and by ea≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall fifteen and ≈øixteen foot, and the Neap-tydes twelve and thirteen foot.

div.head: Inverne≈øs.
div.p:
Lyeth to the ≈øouth end of Cromerty fourteen miles, To ≈øail to Inverne≈øs
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ erne≈øs. from the mouth of Cromerty, keep clo≈øe to the we≈øt ≈øhoar till you come to Chanry-Point, which is a low ≈øandy Point, and there it is very narrow. Being about the Point of Chanry, keep the we≈øt ≈øhoar till you come near to the mouth of Inverne≈øs, where on a low Point of the mouth of the River, you will ≈øee the Ruins of a Cittadel; about a mile from this Cittadel lyeth a Bar, on which is but fifteen foot at low-water; ≈øo that if your Ship draw above fifteen foot water, you mu≈øt ≈øtay for a Tyde. Being over the Bar, you may run up the River Beauly, and Anchor at Ke≈ø≈øock in ten or fifteen Fathom water. The Town of Inverne≈øs lyeth a mile up the River, which is fre≈øh water.

Being got within the Chanry-Point, you may Anchor before the Town of Chanry, as you may ≈øee in the Map. But if any Ship that is not acquainted, and is fearful to adventure up to Inverne≈øs, they may have a Pilot at Cromerty.

div.head: Findhorne.
div.p: Lyeth ea≈øt ≈øouth ea≈øt from Scromerty four Leagues,Findhorne and is a Tyde-Haven, where Ve≈ø≈øels enter at high-water.

div.head: Tarbetne≈øs.
div.p: From Cromerty to Tarbetne≈øs, Tarbetne≈øs the Cour≈øe is north ea≈øt and by north four Leagues, a bold and clean ≈øhoar; only in the Fairway there lyeth a ≈ømall parcel of Rocks, about half a mile from the ≈øhoar, called the Three Kings, which ≈øhew above water.

div.head: Tarbet-Bay, or The Frith of Taine.
div.p: To the northward of Tarbetne≈øs Tarbet-Bay or The Frith of Taine. lyeth into the we≈øtward a deep Bay, called Tarbet-Bay, or The Frith of Taine. Such Ships as have occa≈øion to ≈øail up to Taine mu≈øt take in a Pilot, for there lyeth a Bar about five miles to the we≈øtward of Tarbet-Point, where is but ≈øix foot at low-water. But in the Bay is good Anchoring for all Winds but ea≈øterly.

div.head: Dungesby-head.
div.p: From Tarbet-Point to Dungesby-head, Dungesby-head. the Cour≈øe is north ea≈øt and by north and north north ea≈øt fourteen Leagues. Between which Head and the I≈ølands of Orkney is a Channel, called Pentland-Frith, where is the ≈øtronge≈øt Tyde in all the Coa≈øt of Great Britain.

div.head: THE ISLANDS OF ORKNEY.
div.p: ARE ≈øeveral I≈ølands that lye to the northward of Scotland, in which are many good Harbours, and good ≈øailing between the mo≈øt part of them. The Tydes run very ≈øtrong among≈øt them: You will ≈øee (in the Map of the I≈øles of Orkney, numbred with the Letter R.) ≈øeveral Arrows, which ≈øhew that the Tyde of Flood ≈øetteth the ≈øame way the Arrows Point, and the Tydes of Ebb to the contrary.

div.head: Pomona.
div.p: Pomona. Pomona is the greate≈øt I≈øland, on which is the Town of Kirkwell, where the Bi≈øhop of Orkney re≈øides. In this I≈øland of Pomona are two very good Harbours, Dear≈øound and Cair≈øton.

div.head: Dear≈øound.
div.p: Dear≈øoundLyeth on the north ea≈øt end of Pomona, ju≈øt within the Mulhead, which Head is high land and very remarkable, as you may ≈øee by the making of it in the Map, numbred with the Letter S. The Mulhead is bold and ≈øteep too; the Harbours mouth lyeth from this Head a League, and the Harbours mouth is about a mile over. Keep in the middle, for there lyeth off ≈øome ≈øunk Rocks from Point Ne≈øtin, which is on the Starboard-≈øide going in; being pa≈øt this Point, then edge to the northward, and bring Point Ne≈øtin ea≈øt and by north, and Anchor in five Fathom water at low-water. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt and by ≈øouth. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall ten and twelve foot, and the Neap-tydes ≈øeven and eight foot in this Harbour. The Engli≈øh Convoy and Fi≈øhermen for Iceland, make u≈øe of this Harbour mo≈øt commonly to fill fre≈øh water, and take in Turff for Firing. Provi≈øions are here good and Plenty, all the≈øe I≈ølands afford much Corn. Fi≈øh of all ≈øorts is very plenty and cheap.

div.head: Cair≈øton.
div.p:
Lyeth at the ≈øouth we≈øt end of Pomona, Cair≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and is a good and ≈øafe Harbour, and is a good out-let to the we≈øtward. There are ≈øeveral Channels to ≈øail to it, as you may ≈øee by the Map. There is a good Channel at the ≈øouth end of Pomena, called Ham≈øound. You ≈øail clo≈øe by the Point of Ro≈øne≈øs, leaving the I≈øland Lamholme on the Larboard-≈øide, and ≈øo keep the I≈øland Pomona aboard till you come up to Cair≈øound.

There is a good Channel beween South-Ronal≈øha and Burra, and another broad Sound between the I≈øland of Hoy, Flota, and South-Ronal≈øha. Betweeen the I≈øle of Hoy and Pomona, are many good places to Anchor in, where you ride Land-lock't. The Tydes run in and out very ≈øtrong between the we≈øt end of Hoy and Pomona, where you will have great Riplings and Breaches, as though there were ≈øhoal-water, yet the Channel is bold and deep, and no danger; in the Harbour of Cair≈øton is no manner of Tyde, where you ride with great ≈øafety. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall ten and twelve foot.

div.head: Kirkwell-Road.
div.p: Kirkwell-R ‚Ä¢ ad.To ≈øail into Kirkwell-Road, you mu≈øt ≈øail between Pomona, and Shapin≈øha, leaving the I≈øland Elgar-Holm on the Starboard-≈øide, and the I≈øland Thieves-Holm on the Larboard-≈øide; being about the I≈øland, ≈øtand into Kirkwell-Road, and Anchor before the Town in five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, eight, or nine Fathom water.

div.head: Moonos-Bay.
div.p:
M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nos- ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
There is very good Anchoring to the we≈øtward of Kirkwell-Bay, called Moonos-Bay. There are ≈øeveral ≈øunk Rocks that lye to the northward of Kirkwell-Bay, between it and the I≈øland Gar≈øay. But I would not have any Stranger ≈øail that way but with a Pilot.

div.head: Wire≈øound.
div.p: Wire≈øound.To ≈øail into Wire≈øound from the ea≈øtward you mu≈øt ≈øail into Stron≈øa-Frith, between the Mulhead and Stron≈øa; in which Frith runneth a very ≈øtrong Tyde, e≈øpecially on Spring-tydes, ≈øo that if you ≈øhould Anchor, your Cables and Anchors mu≈øt be very good to hold, be≈øides the Ground is foul. Here you will have great Riplings and Breaches cau≈øed by the ≈øtrength of the Tydes, and yet deep water. Being entred into the Frith between the Mulhead and Stron≈øa, keep over to Shapin≈øa, and ≈øail between it and Green-I≈øland, leaving Shapin≈øa on the Larboard-≈øide, and Green-I≈øland on the Starboard-≈øide, and then ≈øail between Wire, Egle≈øha and Row≈øay, which three I≈ølands make a good Road, called Wire≈øound; you may turn in with a Tyde, there being no danger; only from the ≈øouth end of Egle≈øha lyeth off ≈øome Rocks, of which you mu≈øt have a care, they lye a mile off Bring St. Agnis Church north ea≈øt, or ea≈øt north ea≈øt, and Anchor in ≈øix, ≈øeven, eight, or nine Fathom water. This is a good Road, and but little Tyde, and is u≈øed by the Iceland Fi≈øhermen when they are bound for Iceland.

div.head: Scokne≈øholm.
div.p: There is a narrow Channel to ≈øail out at the north end of Wire≈øound, between Row≈øay and a little I≈øland, called Scokne≈øholm, Scoken≈øholm. where is four Fathom at low-water, keep in the middle between them. But the be≈øt Channel is to go out at the ≈øouth end of Egle≈øha, and ≈øo ≈øail out Westra-Frith, between Row≈øay and Westra, keeping neare≈øt to Row≈øa, for there lyeth ≈øome ≈øunk Rocks about two Miles off from Croskirk on We≈øtra.
There is a Channel between Stron≈øa, Sanda, and Eda into Stron≈øa-Frith, and ≈øo to Wire≈øound, and out of We≈øtra-Frith.

I have given you an Account of the be≈øt Harbours in the≈øe I≈ølands; only there are ≈øeveral others, which are made u≈øe of but by ≈ømall Ve≈ø≈øels, which I have no occa≈øion to mention, my only de≈øign being to harbour Ships in the be≈øt Harbours.

div.head: Faire-I≈øle.
div.p: Between the I≈ølands of Orkney and the I≈ølands of Shetland, is a ≈ømall I≈øland called Fair-I≈øle, Fair-I≈øle. which is inhabited. The Dutch Ea≈øt-India Ships, as they go and come from India, ≈øail between the I≈ølands of Orkney and Shetland, and homeward bound they ≈øend a≈øhoar at this Fair-I≈øland for Letters of Advice; but commonly the Dutch Ea≈øt-India Company ≈øend a Ship to meet them here with Advice.

div.head: THE ISLANDS OF SHETLAND.
div.p: THe≈øe I≈ølands lye away north half ea≈øt from Bokannais in Scotland about five and forty Leagues to the ≈øouthward part of them, called Sumbrough-head, and north ea≈øt from the I≈øland of Orkney ≈øixteen or ≈øeventeen Leagues. Shetland is high Land, and very remarkable, as you may ≈øee by the making of the Land, numbred with the Letter W.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the South part of Shetland, from Sumbrough-head to the I≈øles of Bra≈øey and Nos, and from thence to Laxford and Catford-Sounds.
Sumbrough-head.
div.p: Sumbrough-head. S∆≤mbrough-head is the ≈øouth part of Shetland: between it and Fitfil-head are three Bays, as you may ≈øee in the Map of Shetland, numbred with the Letter W

div.head: Quindel-Bay.
div.p: The be≈øt is Quendel-Bay, and lyeth on the ea≈øt ≈øide of Fitfil-head, and is a good place to Anchor in ≈øix, ≈øeven, or eight Fathom water; the Sea being open but to four Points of the Compa≈øs.

div.head: We≈øt-Voe.
div.p: A little to the we≈øtward of Sumbrough-head is a ≈ømall Bay, called We≈øt-Voe, We≈øt-Voe. where you Anchor in ≈øeven or eight Fathom water, and is a good Road for all Winds, but from the ≈øouth to the ≈øouth ea≈øt.

div.head: Ea≈øt-Voe.
div.p: About a Mile to the northward of Sumbrough-head is a Bay, called Ea≈øt-voe, Ea≈øt-Voe. and lyeth ≈øouth ≈øouth we≈øt in, where you Anchor in three or four Fathom, and is a good Road for all Winds, but north ea≈øt Winds. As you ≈øail in and out you mu≈øt keep a Cables length. At the Entry into this Bay is another Bay, and runneth in we≈øt and by north, where is ≈øhoal-water, not above four and five foot.
About ≈øix miles to the northward of Sumbrough-head is a little Inlet, where are two Bays, Lewenwick and Sandwick.

div.head: Lewenwick.
div.p: Lewenwick Lewenwick. lyeth in we≈øt north we≈øt, and we≈øt and by north; and as ≈øoon as the Bay opens, you ≈øail in we≈øt, and we≈øt and by ≈øouth, and Anchor in ≈øeven and eight Fathom water.

div.head: Sandwick.
div.p: Sandwich Sandwick. runneth in north, and north and by ea≈øt, and is a little Bay, where you Anchor in ≈øeven Fathom water. The Point of Nonnai≈øe lyeth from Lewenwick about a Mile.

div.head: I≈øland of Mu≈øa.
div.p:
From the Point of Nonnai≈øe lyeth the I≈øland of Mu≈øa I≈øland of Mu≈øa. north ea≈øt about a mile: there is a Channel between the I≈øland and
the Main. North we≈øt and by north, and north north we≈øt from this I≈øland, is a little Inlet going in north, called Eths-Noe, where is but ten and twelve foot.

div.head: Bra≈øey.
div.p:
„Äà‚óä„Äâ
From the I≈øland of Mu≈øa to the Head of Bra≈øey or Wart-hill, the Cour≈øe is north two Leagues. Between the I≈øland of Bra≈øey and the Main is the going into Bra≈øey-Sound, leaving Bra≈øey on the Starboard-≈øide, there is no manner of danger in ≈øailing in and out at Bra≈øey-Sound. You may Anchor before the Town of Lerwick in five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, eight, nine, or ten Fathom-water Land-lock. The Earl of Sandwich, in the Year 1665. in the War with Holland. Anchored here with the Engli≈øh Fleet under his Command. This is a mo≈øt excellent Harbour, and much frequented by the Dutch Herring-Fi≈øhers Bu≈ø≈øes; for at the≈øe I≈ølands the Dutch begin their Summer-herring fi≈øhing, and ≈øo follow the Fi≈øh from this Place to the Coa≈øt of Scotland, and the Coa≈øt of England; they begin to fi≈øh at Shetland about the middle of June, and continue fi≈øhing from thence to Yarmouth, till the latter end of September: there have been five hundred Sail of Dutch Herring-Bu≈ø≈øes at a time in Bra≈øey-Sound. Here you have fre≈øh water, and Turff for firing, and great plenty of ≈øeveral-≈øorts of Fi≈øh.

div.head: I≈øland of No≈ø≈øe.
div.p: ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe.You may very ea≈øily know the going into Bra≈øey-Sound by the I≈øland of No≈ø≈øe, which lyeth to the ea≈øtward of the I≈øland Bra≈øey, the ea≈øtward part of which I≈øland is called Hang-cliff, being a high ≈øteep Cliff by the Sea ≈øide, and hanging over into the Sea. Wart-hill, or Sandwich-hill is very remarkable, as you may ≈øee in the Map of Bra≈øey, numbred with the Letter T. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth ea≈øt and by ≈øouth. The Spring-tydes ri≈øe and fall eight foot, and at a Neap-tyde five foot; here is but a ≈ømall Tyde: the Flood cometh into the ≈øouth Entrance, and runneth out at the north Entrance, and the Tyde of Ebb to the contrary: the Tydes are ≈øtronge≈øt at the north Entrance.

div.head: Holme of Crue≈øter.
div.p: B ‚Ä¢ ing in Bra≈øey-Sound, and that you would ≈øail out at the north end, called the North-Sound, keep the Main-≈øide till you are pa≈øt a ≈ømall I≈øland, called The Holme of Crue≈øter, The Holme of Crue≈øter for to the we≈øtward of this I≈øland lyeth ≈øome ≈øunk Rocks, called Loofhabor, being pa≈øt the≈øe Rocks, ≈øteer away to the northward, and when you come to the fir≈øt narrow Entrance, there is a middle bank on which is but fifteen foot water; but there is a narrow Channel of eighteen foot water of each ≈øide of it; you may keep of either ≈øide of it, the ≈øhoars being bold, and then you come into a broader place, and then narrow again, which is the northermo≈øt Pa≈ø≈øage; you mu≈øt keep the Main aboard, and go clo≈øe by the ≈ømall I≈øland or Rock called Scotland, for there lyeth ≈øome ≈øunk Rocks off from Bra≈øey ≈øide, as you may ≈øee ≈øee in the large Map of Bra≈øey: being out at the north end, you have a good Channel out between Beo≈øter-I≈øland and Green-I≈øland into the Sea.

div.head: The Voes.
div.p: Between the I≈øland of Bra≈øey and a head Land called the Mull of E≈øweek, lyeth in four deep Sounds and Bays, called by the Inhabitants Voes: the ≈øouthernmo≈øt is called Deal's Voe, Deal's Voe, and lyeth two Miles to the northward of the I≈øland Bra≈øey, and is a Bay, lying in ≈øouth we≈øt and by ≈øouth two Miles, but not above a quarter of a Mile broad. About three quarters of a Mile from Kebe≈øter-Point, which is on the ≈øouth ≈øide, there lyeth a Rock called Toagrood, and ≈øheweth at half-tyde. It beareth from the ≈øaid Point of Kebe≈øter north ea≈øt and by north.

div.head: Laxford-Voe.
div.p: A Mile to the northward of Deal's Voe is Laxford Voe, Laxford Voe. lying ≈øouth we≈øt and by ≈øouth two Miles, much like Deal's Voe, where is three, four, five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, eight, nine and ten Fathom water clear Ground, and good Anchoring.

div.head: Web≈øters-Voe.
div.p:
A little to the northward of Laxford-Voe, lyeth Web≈øters-Voe, Web≈øter's-Voe. a Mile in we≈øt and by
≈øouth, where is good Anchoring in four, five, ≈øix, ≈øeven, and eight Fathom water.

div.head: Catford-Voe.
div.p: Catford: Voe. Catford-Voe is the northernmo≈øt and the be≈øt, for there you ride Land-lockt for all Winds. This is a mo≈øt excellent Bay, and able to hold a Navy Royal, where you may Anchor in what depth of water you plea≈øe, from fourteen Fathom to three Fathom clear Ground.

From Sumbrough-head to Nonnais, the Flood runneth to the northward; but from Nonnais to Bra≈øey, the Ebb falleth to the northwards, and the Flood to the contrary, as the Ebb doth from Nonnais to Sumbrough-head, ≈øo that the Tydes part at Nonnais.

div.head: A De≈øcription of the We≈øt-Coa≈øt of the ≈øouth part of Shetland, from Fitfil-head to Scallaway.
Col≈øa-I≈øland.
div.p: FROM Fitfil-head to the I≈øland of Col≈øa, Col≈øa-I≈øland. the Cour≈øe is north north we≈øt two Miles, and from Col≈øa to the I≈øland St. Ringins, St. Ringins I≈øland. the Cour≈øe is north and by we≈øt two Miles. This I≈øland is joyned to the Main by a little I≈øthmus of Sand, which overfloweth at ≈øome high Tydes. To the ≈øouthward of this I≈øthmus, and within the I≈øland, is a fair ≈øandy Bay, where is a good Road to Anchor in ≈øeven, eight, or nine Fathom. There is a good Road to the northward of this I≈øthmus, where is a good Road for ea≈øterly and ≈øoutherly Winds.

div.head: Little Hevra and Great Hevra.
div.p: Two Miles north and by we≈øt from the I≈øland of St. Ringins are two I≈ølands, called Little Hevra and Great Hevra; Little Hevra and Great Hevra. between which and the Main is the little I≈øland, called the Holme of Maywick. Between this I≈øland, and the I≈øland Hevra, is the Entrance into Clift-Sound, which is a fair and clean Sound, and runneth in north half ea≈øt two Leagues and a half, having the I≈øland of Ea≈øt-Buro, and the I≈øland Tronzo on the we≈øt, and the main Land on the Ea≈øt, and a mile broad in ≈øome places, and other places le≈øs, as you may ≈øee in the Map; where you may Anchor in good Ground, from eighteen Fathom to five Fathom. At the northernmo≈øt part of this Sound the I≈øland of Tronzo lyeth within a Cables length of the Main, at which narrow place is a Bar, where is but ≈øix and ≈øeven foot water at low-water, and eleven and twelve foot at high-water to ≈øail over the Bar, Keep clo≈øe to the Main, and within half a Mile of the Town of Scallaway.

The be≈øt Channel to go into Scallaway, How ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Sail i ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Scalla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
is to ≈øail without the I≈øland of Buro, and bring the Ca≈øtle of Scallaway north ea≈øt and by ea≈øt; there is a leading Mark, which is to keep the Ca≈øtle of Scallaway ju≈øt open of the ≈øouth ≈øide of Green-I≈øland, and this Mark will carry you in between Buro, Oxna, and Papa, leaving Buro on the Starboard-≈øide, and Oxna and Papa on the Larboard-≈øide, and ≈øo ≈øail in between Green-I≈øland, and the little I≈øland called Narry, which are not above a Cables length a≈øunder: being pa≈øt the≈øe I≈ølands, run in with the Ca≈øtle open before the Town, in four, three, or two Fathom water. It floweth here at Full and Change ≈øouth ≈øouth ea≈øt, and ≈øouth ea≈øt by ≈øouth.

From Sumbrough-head to Scallaway the Tyde of Ebb runneth to the northwards, and the Flood to the contrary. Here I found the Variation to be ≈øix Degrees we≈øterly;Variat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and the ≈øame at the I≈ølands of Orkney.

The north part of the I≈øland of Shetland I had not time to Survey, the Summer being well ≈øpent; at which time I went to the I≈ølands of Orkney, and from thence to Cromerly and Inverne≈øs; from which place I parted at the latter end of October in the Year 1685.

I ≈øurvey'd Liverpool, the I≈øle of Man, Carreck-fergus, Dublin, Kin≈øale and Cork, which is all that is ≈øurvey'd, and is the mo≈øt u≈øefulle≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary part to Navigation. I could heartily wi≈øh that the we≈øt part of Ireland and Scotland may hereafter be ≈øurvey'd, &c.
